5.verse: You have determined the length of my days, and my life is nothing compared to You. Even the longest life is only a breath.” [pause]

6.verse: In truth, each of us journeys through life like a shadow. We busy ourselves accomplishing nothing, piling up assets we can never keep; We can’t even know who will end up with those things.

7.verse: In light of all this, Lord, what am I really waiting for? You are my hope.

8.verse: Keep me from all the wrong I would do; don’t let the foolish laugh at me.

9.verse: I am quiet; I keep my mouth closed because this has come from You.

10.verse: Take Your curse from me; I can’t endure Your punishment.

11.verse: You discipline us for our sins. Like a moth, You consume everything we treasure; it’s evident we are merely a breath. [pause]

12.verse: Hear me, O Eternal One; listen to my pleading, and don’t ignore my tears Because I am estranged from You— a wanderer like my fathers before me.

13.verse: Look away from me so I might have a chance to recover my joy and smile again before I lay this life down and am no more.

1.verse: Psalm 40 - For the worship leader. A song of David. I waited a long time for the Eternal; He finally knelt down to hear me. He listened to my weak and whispered cry.

2.verse: He reached down and drew me from the deep, dark hole where I was stranded, mired in the muck and clay. With a gentle hand, He pulled me out To set me down safely on a warm rock; He held me until I was steady enough to continue the journey again.

3.verse: As if that were not enough, because of Him my mind is clearing up. Now I have a new song to sing— a song of praise to the One who saved me. Because of what He’s done, many people will see and come to trust in the Eternal.

4.verse: Surely those who trust the Eternal— who don’t trust in proud, powerful people Or in people who care little for reality, chasing false gods— surely they are happy, as I have become.

5.verse: You have done so many wonderful things, had so many tender thoughts toward us, Eternal my God, that go on and on, ever increasing. Who can compare with You?

6.verse: Sacrifices and offerings are not what You want, but You’ve opened my ears, and now I understand. Burnt offerings and sin offerings are not what please You.

7.verse: So I said, “See, I have come to do Your will, as it is inscribed of me in the scroll.

8.verse: I am pleased to live how You want, my God. Your law is etched into my heart and my soul.”

9.verse: I have encouraged Your people with the message of righteousness, in Your great assembly (look and see), I haven’t kept quiet about these things; You know this, Eternal One.

10.verse: I have not kept Your righteousness to myself, sealed up in the secret places of my heart; instead, I boldly tell others how You save and how loyal You are. I haven’t been shy to talk about Your love, nor have I been afraid to tell Your truth before the great assembly of Your people.

11.verse: Please, Eternal One, don’t hold back Your kind ways from me. I need Your strong love and truth to stand watch over me and keep me from harm.

12.verse: Right now I can’t see because I am surrounded by troubles; my sins and shortcomings have caught up to me, so I am swimming in darkness. Like the hairs on my head, there are too many to count, so my heart deserts me.

13.verse: O Eternal One, please rescue me. O Eternal One, hurry; I need Your help.

14.verse: May those who are trying to destroy me be humiliated and ashamed instead; May those who want to ruin my reputation be cut off and embarrassed.

15.verse: May those who try to catch me off guard, those who look at me and say, “Aha, we’ve trapped you,” be caught in their own shame instead.

16.verse: But may all who look for You discover true joy and happiness in You; May those who cherish how You save them always say, “O Eternal One, You are great and are first in our hearts.”

17.verse: Meanwhile, I am empty and need so much, but I know the Lord is thinking of me. You are my help; only You can save me, my True God. Please hurry.

1.verse: Psalm 41 - For the worship leader. A song of David. The first four books of Psalms end with a variation of the doxology found in verse 13: “Blessed is the Eternal, the True God of Israel. Always and Eternal. Amen and Amen.” This declaration not only provides a natural break—a seam—between the five books, but it also summarizes an essential theme of the psalms. You see, the Book of Psalms is primarily a book of praise to God for His creation, mercy, and salvation. Even when life is hard, our enemies strong, and our health poor, God can be praised for life itself and the ultimate victory to come for those who trust Him. Blessed are those who consider the helpless. The Eternal will stay near them, leading them to safety in times of bitter struggle.

2.verse: The Eternal defends them and preserves them, and His blessing will find them in the land He gave them. He moves ahead to frustrate their enemies’ plans.

3.verse: When sickness comes, the Eternal is beside them— to comfort them on their sickbeds and restore them to health.

4.verse: And me? I cry out to Him, “Heal my soul, O Eternal One, and show mercy because I have sinned against You!”

5.verse: My enemies are talking about me even now: “When will death come for him and his name be forgotten?”

6.verse: As they sit with me under my roof, their well wishes are empty lies. They listen to my story and then turn it around to tell their own version on the street.

7.verse: Across the city, crowds whisper lies about me. Their hate is strong, and they search for ways to harm me.

8.verse: Some are saying: “Some vile disease has gotten hold of him. The bed he lies in will be his deathbed.”

9.verse: Even my best friend, my confidant who has eaten my bread will stab me in the back.

10.verse: But You, Eternal One, show mercy to me. Extend Your gracious hand, and help me up. I need to pay them back for what they’ve done to me.

11.verse: I realize now that Your favor has come to me, for my enemies have yet to declare victory over me.

12.verse: You know and uphold me—a man of honor. You grant me strength and life forever in Your presence.

13.verse: Blessed is the Eternal, the True God of Israel. Always and Eternal. Amen and Amen.

1.verse: Book Two - This second book of psalms (Psalms 42–72) has a few unique features. First, it is the only book of the five that contains psalms ascribed to the sons of Korah, a group of Levite temple singers. Second, it uses two rather obscure Hebrew terms in the superscriptions of almost half of these psalms. Maskil, which may be related to contemplation, is translated “contemplative poem” or “song” (42; 44–45; 52–55) and miktam, whose meaning is unclear, is translated “a prayer” (56–60). Third, in referring to God this second book shows a preference for the word “God” over the name “the Eternal One” that appears as “YHWH” in the Hebrew Scriptures. Throughout the Bible, the creator and covenant God is referred to in many ways. Generally speaking, the names and titles used indicate something of His character and nature. The title “God” implies His unique majesty and power; no one is like Him. The name, translated “The Eternal One” and also “The Eternal,” is God’s covenant name revealed uniquely to Israel. As the translation suggests, the divine name implies that the one True God transcends time and yet He is “with” His people. Psalm 42 - For the worship leader. A contemplative song of the sons of Korah. My soul is dry and thirsts for You, True God, as a deer thirsts for water.

2.verse: I long for the True God who lives. When can I stand before Him and feel His comfort?

3.verse: Right now I’m overwhelmed by my sorrow and pain; I can’t stop feasting on my tears. People crowd around me and say, “Where is your True God whom you claim will save?”

4.verse: With a broken heart, I remember times before When I was with Your people. Those were better days. I used to lead them happily into the True God’s house, Singing with joy, shouting thanksgivings with abandon, joining the congregation in the celebration.

5.verse: Why am I so overwrought? Why am I so disturbed? Why can’t I just hope in God? Despite all my emotions, I will believe and praise the One who saves me and is my life.

6.verse: My God, my soul is so traumatized; the only help is remembering You wherever I may be; From the land of the Jordan to Hermon’s high place to Mount Mizar.

7.verse: In the roar of Your waterfalls, ancient depths surge, calling out to the deep. All Your waves break over me; am I drowning?

8.verse: Yet in the light of day, the Eternal shows me His love. When night settles in and all is dark, He keeps me company— His soothing song, a prayerful melody to the True God of my life.

9.verse: Even still, I will say to the True God, my rock and strength: “Why have You forgotten me? Why must I live my life so depressed, crying endlessly while my enemies have the upper hand?”

10.verse: My enemies taunt me. They shatter my soul the way a sword shatters a man’s bones. They keep taunting all the day long, “Where is He, your True God?”

11.verse: Why am I so overwrought, Why am I so disturbed? Why can’t I just hope in God? Despite all my emotions, I will believe and praise the One who saves me, my God.

1.verse: Psalm 43 - Plead for me; clear my name, O God. Prove me innocent before immoral people; Save me from their lies, their unjust thoughts and deeds.

2.verse: You are the True God—my shelter, my protector, the one whom I lean on. Why have You turned away from me? Rejected me? Why must I go around, overwrought, mourning, suffering under the weight of my enemies?

3.verse: O my God, shine Your light and truth to help me see clearly, To lead me to Your holy mountain, to Your home.

4.verse: Then I will go to God’s altar with nothing to hide. I will go to God, my rapture; I will sing praises to You and play my strings, unloading my cares, unleashing my joys, to You, God, my God.

5.verse: O my soul, why are you so overwrought? Why are you so disturbed? Why can’t I just hope in God? Despite all my emotions, I will hope in God again. I will believe and praise the One who saves me and is my life, My Savior and my God.

1.verse: Psalm 44 - For the worship leader. A contemplative song of the sons of Korah. With our own ears, O God, we have heard the stories our ancestors recited of Your deeds in their days, days long past— how You saved the day.

2.verse: With a powerful hand, You drove the nations from this land, but then You planted our parents here. You fought for us against people of this land; You set our parents free to enjoy its goodness.

3.verse: They did not win the land with their swords. It wasn’t their strength that won them victory. It was Your strength—Your right hand, Your arm, and the light of Your presence that gave them success, for You loved them.

4.verse: You are my King, my God! You ordained victories for Jacob and his people!

5.verse: You are our victory, pushing back the enemy; at the sound of Your name, we crush the opposition.

6.verse: I don’t trust in my weapons or in my strength to win me victory.

7.verse: But You rescue us from our foes; You shame our enemies.

8.verse: We shout Your name all day long; we will praise Your name forever! [pause]

9.verse: But wait, God, where have You gone? Why have You shamed us? Why do our armies stand alone?

10.verse: Without Your help we must retreat from our enemy, and the very ones who despise us pillage us.

11.verse: You have offered us up to our enemies, like sheep to the slaughter, meat for their feast, and You have dispersed us among the nations.

12.verse: You sold Your people for mere pennies, and You gained nothing from the deal.

13.verse: You have made us a joke to our friends and neighbors, mocked and ridiculed by all those around us.

14.verse: You have brought us infamy among the nations and made us an object of scorn and laughter to our neighbors.

15.verse: Disgrace follows me everywhere I go; I am constantly embarrassed. Shame is written across my face

16.verse: Because of the taunting and berating of those who are against me, because the enemy seeks revenge against me.

17.verse: All this has happened to us, yet we have never forgotten You; we have not broken Your covenant with us.

18.verse: Our hearts stayed true to You; we have never left Your path; we follow on.

19.verse: Yet You have tested us, left us defeated in a land of jackals, and shrouded us with the veil of death.

20.verse: Even if we had forgotten the name of our God or offered praise to another god,

21.verse: Would not the True God have known it? For He can see the hidden places of our hearts.

22.verse: On Your behalf, our lives are endangered constantly; we are like sheep awaiting slaughter.

23.verse: Wake up, Lord! Why do You slumber? Get up! Do not reject us any longer!

24.verse: Why are You still hiding from us? Why are You still ignoring our suffering and trouble?

25.verse: Look and You will see our souls now dwell in the dust; our bodies hug the earth.

26.verse: Rise up and help us; restore us for the sake of Your boundless love.

1.verse: Psalm 45 - For the worship leader. A contemplative song of the sons of Korah to the tune “The Lilies.” A love song. My heart is bursting with a new song; lyrics to my king erupt like a spring for my king, to my king; my tongue is the pen of a poet, ready and willing.

2.verse: Better by far are you than all others, my king; gracious words flow from your lips; indeed, God has blessed you forever.

3.verse: Psalm 45 describes the beauty, power, and influence of God’s anointed king and may have been composed in honor of a royal wedding. Whether we realize it or not, the overall well-being of a nation is tied directly to its leaders. When the leaders are just and make good decisions, then the welfare of a nation is secure. But when leaders are unjust and make poor decisions, and they pursue personal agendas rather than the public good, then nations suffer. This is why Scripture instructs those of faith to pray for all people everywhere, especially that those in authority would lead the world to dignity and peace (1 Timothy 2:1-3). Psalm 45 celebrates that rare breed, a godly king who pursues truth and justice. It anticipates a joyful union and future children who will one day follow in the steps of their father. May the world witness a new breed of leader, fashioned in the image of this psalm. With your sword at your side, you are glorious, majestic, a mighty warrior.

4.verse: Ride on in splendor; ride into battle victorious, for the sake of truth, humility, and justice. Perform awesome acts, trained by your powerful right hand.

5.verse: Razor-sharp arrows leap from your bow to pierce the heart of the king’s foes; they lie, defeated, before you.

6.verse: O God, Your throne is eternal; You will rule your kingdom with a scepter of justice.

7.verse: You have loved what is right and hated what is evil. That is why God, your God, has anointed you with the oil of gladness and lifted you above your companions.

8.verse: All of your clothing is drenched in the rich scent of myrrh, aloes, and cassia; In palaces decked out with ivory, beautiful stringed instruments play for your pleasure.

9.verse: At a royal wedding with the daughters of kings among the guests of honor, your bride-queen stands at your right, adorned in gold from Ophir.

10.verse: Hear this, daughter; pay close attention to what I am about to say: you must forget your people and even your father’s house.

11.verse: Because the king yearns for your beauty, humble yourself before him, for he is now your lord.

12.verse: The daughter of Tyre arrives with a gift; the wealthy will bow and plead for your favor.

13.verse: A stunning bride, the king’s daughter waits within; her clothing is skillfully woven with gold.

14.verse: She, in her richly embroidered gown, is carried to the king, her virgin companions following close behind.

15.verse: They walk in a spirit of celebration and gratefulness. In delight, they enter the palace of the king.

16.verse: O king, in this place where your ancestors reigned, you will have sons; you will make them princes throughout all the land.

17.verse: I will make sure your name is remembered by all future generations so that the people will offer you thanks and praise now and forever.

1.verse: Psalm 46 - For the worship leader. A song of the sons of Korah, a song for sopranos. This song is attributed to the sons of Korah. It praises God for His strength and protection and for Jerusalem and its temple where God uniquely dwells. It invites the world to witness a future when wars and striving will cease and all the nations know and worship the one True God. God is our shelter and our strength. When troubles seem near, God is nearer, and He’s ready to help. So why run and hide?

2.verse: No fear, no pacing, no biting fingernails. When the earth spins out of control, we are sure and fearless. When mountains crumble and the waters run wild, we are sure and fearless.

3.verse: Even in heavy winds and huge waves, or as mountains shake, we are sure and fearless. [pause]

4.verse: A pure stream flows—never to be cut off— bringing joy to the city where God makes His home, the sacred site where the Most High chooses to live.

5.verse: The True God never sleeps and always resides in the city of joy; He makes it unstoppable, unshakable. When it awakes at dawn, the True God has already been at work.

6.verse: Trouble is on the horizon for the outside nations, not long until kingdoms will fall; God’s voice thunders and the earth shakes.

7.verse: You know the Eternal, the Commander of heavenly armies, surrounds us and protects us; the True God of Jacob is our shelter, close to His heart. [pause]

8.verse: Come, gaze, fix your eyes on what the Eternal can do. Amazing, He has worked desolation here on this battlefield, earth.

9.verse: God can stop wars anywhere in the world. He can make scrap of all weapons: snap bows, shatter spears, and burn shields.

10.verse: “Be still, be calm, see, and understand I am the True God. I am honored among all the nations. I am honored over all the earth.”

11.verse: You know the Eternal, the Commander of heavenly armies, surrounds us and protects us; the True God of Jacob is our shelter, close to His heart. [pause]

1.verse: Psalm 47 - For the worship leader. A song of the sons of Korah. Clap your hands, all of you; raise your voices joyfully and loudly. Give honor for the True God of the universe;

2.verse: Here’s why: The Eternal, the Most High, is awesome and deserves our great respect. He is the great King over everything in this world.

3.verse: He’s helped us win wars, suppressed our enemies, and made nations bow at our feet.

4.verse: He decides the extent of our inheritance and selects the land where we and our children will live, for we are the pride of Jacob, the ones He loves. [pause]

5.verse: The True God ascends the throne acclaimed by shouts of the people. The Eternal is announced by the blast of a trumpet.

6.verse: Sing! Shout! Play instruments! Praise our God and King; sing praises to Him who is worthy.

7.verse: For He is the King of all the earth. Sing praise, all who can. Put words to music, and then sing praises

8.verse: At the feet of the God who sits on His holy throne, ruling over all the nations.

9.verse: All those with influence in this world—princes, kings, and satraps— gather with those who follow Abraham’s God. For these defenders belong to God who reigns over the nations!

1.verse: Psalm 48 - A song of the sons of Korah. The Eternal is great and mighty, worthy of great praise in the city of our True God, upon His holy mountain.

2.verse: Situated high above, Mount Zion is beautiful to see, the pleasure of the entire earth. Mount Zion, in the north, is the city of the great King.

3.verse: In her palaces, the True God has revealed Himself as a mighty fortress.

4.verse: Not long ago, enemy kings gathered together and moved forward as one to attack the city.

5.verse: When they saw Mount Zion, they were amazed; amazement became fear, then panic. They fled for their lives.

6.verse: They were overtaken by terror, trembling in anguish like a woman in childbirth.

7.verse: God, You shattered the ships of Tarshish with the mighty east wind.

8.verse: As we have heard stories of Your greatness, now we have also seen it with our own eyes right here, in the city of the Eternal, the Commander of heavenly armies. Right here, in our God’s city, the True God will preserve her forever. [pause]

9.verse: We have meditated upon Your loyal love, O God, within Your holy temple.

10.verse: Just as Your name reaches to the ends of the earth, O God, so Your praise flows there too; Your right hand holds justice.

11.verse: So because of Your judgments, may Mount Zion be delighted! May the villages of Judah celebrate!

12.verse: Explore Zion; make an accounting, note all her towers;

13.verse: Reflect upon her defenses; stroll through her palaces So that you can tell the coming generation all about her.

14.verse: For so is God, our True God, forever and ever; He will be our guide till the end.

1.verse: Psalm 49 - For the worship leader. A song of the sons of Korah. Some songs are described as “wisdom psalms.” Similar in theme to the short sayings of Proverbs or the reflective essays of Ecclesiastes, these songs offer practical advice to the worshiper of the one True God. In Psalm 49 we find a meditation on wealth and wisdom, but others describe daily activities (127–128; 133), encouragement when evil succeeds (37; 73), and the results of following God or wickedness (112). The purpose of these songs is to edify those who sing and those who hear, reminding them, and us, how to live life as God intends. Listen up, everyone! All you who reside in this world, give an ear!

2.verse: Everyone—rich and poor, young and old, wise and foolish, humble and mighty—

3.verse: My mouth will overflow with wisdom; the reflections of my heart will guide you to understand the nature of life.

4.verse: I will tune my ear to the words of a proverb; to the sounds of a harp, I will reveal my riddle.

5.verse: Why should I be afraid when dark evils swirl about me, when I am walking among the sin of evildoers—

6.verse: Those who depend on their own fortunes, who boast about their earthly riches?

7.verse: One person can’t grant salvation to another or make a payment to the True God for another.

8.verse: Redeeming a life is costly; no premium is enough, ever enough,

9.verse: That one’s body might live on forever and never fear the grave’s decay.

10.verse: Everyone knows that even the wisest ones die, perishing together with the foolish and the stupid. For all die—beggars and kings, fools and wise men. Their wealth remains behind for others.

11.verse: Although they wish to dwell in fine houses forever, their graves are their real resting places. Their homes are for all future generations, yet for a while they have named lands after themselves.

12.verse: [No one, regardless of how rich or important, can live forever; he is] just like the animals that perish and decay.

13.verse: This is the destiny of those foolish souls who have faith only in themselves; this will be the end of those happy to follow in their ways. [pause]

14.verse: The fate of fools is the grave, and just like sheep, death will feast on them. The righteous will rule over them at dawn, their bodies, their outward forms, rotting in the grave far away from their great mansions.

15.verse: But God will reach into the grave and save my life from its power. He will fetch me and take me into His eternal house. [pause]

16.verse: Do not be afraid of the rich and powerful as their prestige and honor grow,

17.verse: For they cannot take anything with them when they die. Their fame and glory will not follow them into the grave.

18.verse: During their lives, they seek every blessing and advantage because others praise you when you’ve done well.

19.verse: But they will soon join their ancestors, for all of time, among the tombs of the faithless—a place of no light.

20.verse: Anyone who is rich or important without understanding is just like the animals that perish and decay.

1.verse: Psalm 50 - A song of Asaph. The Mighty God, the Eternal—God of past, present, and future— has spoken over the world, calling together all things from sunrise to sunset.

2.verse: From Zion, that perfectly beautiful holy place, shines the radiance of God.

3.verse: Our God will come, and He will not enter on a whisper. A fire will devour the earth before Him; the wind will storm wildly about Him.

4.verse: He calls heaven above and earth below to assist in bringing judgment on His people.

5.verse: “Gather up those who are aligned with Me; bring them to Me; bring everyone who belongs to Me who have made covenant sacrifice.”

6.verse: And the heavens shout of His justice, for He is the True God, an honest judge. [pause]

7.verse: “Listen, My people, I have something to say: O Israel, My testimony comes against you; I am God, your God.

8.verse: I am not going to scold you because of your sacrifices; your burnt offerings are always before Me.

9.verse: I will not accept the best bull from your fields or goats from your meadow,

10.verse: For they are already Mine, just as the forest beast and the cattle grazing over a thousand hills are Mine.

11.verse: Every bird flying over the mountains I know; every animal roaming over the fields belongs to Me.

12.verse: I would not come to you if I were hungry, for the world and all it contains are Mine.

13.verse: Do you really think I eat bull meat? Or drink goat’s blood?

14.verse: Set out a sacrifice I can accept: your thankfulness. Be true to your word to the Most High.

15.verse: When you are in trouble, call for Me. I will come and rescue you, and you will honor Me.”

16.verse: But to those acting against Him, God says, “Who do you think you are? Listing off My laws, acting as if your life is in alignment with My ways?

17.verse: For it’s clear that you despise My guidance; you throw My wise words over your shoulder.

18.verse: You play with thieves, spend your time with adulterers.

19.verse: Evil runs out of your mouth; your tongue is wrapped in deceit.

20.verse: You sit back and gossip about your brother; you slander your mother’s son.

21.verse: While you did these things, I kept silent; somehow you got the idea that I was like you. But now My silence ends, and I am going to indict you. I’ll state the charge against you clearly, face-to-face.

22.verse: All you who have forgotten Me, your God, should think about what I have said, or I will tear you apart and leave no one to save you.

23.verse: Set out a sacrifice I can accept: your thankfulness. Do this, and you will honor Me. Those who straighten up their lives will know the saving grace of God.”

1.verse: Psalm 51 - For the worship leader. A song of David after Nathan the prophet accused him of infidelity with Bathsheba. One of the most difficult episodes in King David’s life was his affair with Bathsheba and all that resulted from it. Psalm 51 reflects the emotions he felt after Nathan confronted him with stealing Bathsheba and murdering her husband, Uriah (2 Samuel 11–12). At one time or another, all people experience the painful consequences of sin. Psalm 51 has been a comfort and a help to millions who have prayed these words as their own. It invites all who are broken to come before God and lean upon His compassion. It teaches that we need not only to be forgiven for the wrong we have done, but we also need to be cleansed of its effects on us. Ultimately, it helps us recognize that if we are to be healed, it is the work of God to create in us a heart that is clean and a spirit that is strong. Look on me with a heart of mercy, O God, according to Your generous love. According to Your great compassion, wipe out every consequence of my shameful crimes.

2.verse: Thoroughly wash me, inside and out, of all my crooked deeds. Cleanse me from my sins.

3.verse: For I am fully aware of all I have done wrong, and my guilt is there, staring me in the face.

4.verse: It was against You, only You, that I sinned, for I have done what You say is wrong, right before Your eyes. So when You speak, You are in the right. When You judge, Your judgments are pure and true.

5.verse: For I was guilty from the day I was born, a sinner from the time my mother became pregnant with me.

6.verse: But still, You long to enthrone truth throughout my being; in unseen places deep within me, You show me wisdom.

7.verse: Cleanse me of my wickedness with hyssop, and I will be clean. If You wash me, I will be whiter than snow.

8.verse: Help me hear joy and happiness as my accompaniment, so my bones, which You have broken, will dance in delight instead.

9.verse: Cover Your face so You will not see my sins, and erase my guilt from the record.

10.verse: Create in me a clean heart, O God; restore within me a sense of being brand new.

11.verse: Do not throw me far away from Your presence, and do not remove Your Holy Spirit from me.

12.verse: Give back to me the deep delight of being saved by You; let Your willing Spirit sustain me.

13.verse: If You do, I promise to teach rebels Your ways and help sinners find their way back to You.

14.verse: Free me from the guilt of murder, of shedding a man’s blood, O God who saves me. Now my tongue, which was used to destroy, will be used to sing with deep delight of how right and just You are.

15.verse: O Lord, pry open my lips that this mouth will sing joyfully of Your greatness.

16.verse: I would surrender my dearest possessions or destroy all that I prize to prove my regret, but You don’t take pleasure in sacrifices or burnt offerings.

17.verse: What sacrifice I can offer You is my broken spirit because a broken spirit, O God, a heart that honestly regrets the past, You won’t detest.

18.verse: Be good to Zion; grant her Your favor. Make Jerusalem’s walls steady and strong.

19.verse: Then there will be sacrifices made, burnt offerings and whole burnt offerings, With right motives that will delight You. And costly young bulls will be offered up to Your altar, only the best.

1.verse: Psalm 52 - For the worship leader. A contemplative song of David when the Edomite Doeg told Saul that David had received help from Ahimelech. Psalm 52 recalls the callous way Doeg and Saul put to death the 85 priests of Nob (1 Samuel 22:6–19). The psalm ends with a memorable image: the one who keeps faith with God is like a lush olive tree cared for in His garden. While those who do not trust in Him are snatched up and torn away, those who do right will flourish under His care. Why do you boast of all the trouble you stir up, O mighty one, when the constant, unfailing love of God is what truly lasts?

2.verse: Have you listened to yourself? Your tongue is like a sharp razor, full of lies that slash and tear right to the soul.

3.verse: You’ve fallen in love with evil and have no interest in what He calls good. You prefer your own lies to speaking what is true. [pause]

4.verse: You love words that destroy people, don’t you, lying tongue?

5.verse: You won’t be smiling when the True God brings His justice and destroys you forever. He will come into your home, snatch you away, and pull you from the land of the living. [pause]

6.verse: Those who are just will see what happens to you and be afraid. And some of them will laugh and say,

7.verse: “Hey, look! Over there is the one who didn’t take shelter in the True God; Instead, he trusted in his great wealth and got what he wanted by destroying others!”

8.verse: But my life is abundant—like a lush olive tree cared for at the house of the one True God. I put my trust in His kind love forever and ever; it will never fail.

9.verse: Because of all You have done, I will humble myself and thank You forever. With Your faithful people at my side, I will put my hope in Your good reputation.

1.verse: Psalm 53 - For the worship leader. A contemplative song of David. A song for the dance. The foolish are convinced deep down that there is no God. Their souls are polluted, and they commit gross injustice. Not one of them does good.

2.verse: From heaven the one True God examines the earth to see if any understand the big picture, if any seek to know the True God.

3.verse: All have turned back to their wicked ways; they’ve become totally perverse. Not one of them does good, not even one.

4.verse: Do the wicked relish their ignorance, the wicked ones who consume My people as if they were bread and fail to call upon the True God?

5.verse: They trembled with great fear, though they’d never been afraid before, Because the True God ravaged the bones of those who rose against you. You humiliated them because the True God spat them out.

6.verse: Oh, that the liberation of Israel would come out of Zion! When the True God reclaims His people, let Jacob celebrate; let Israel rejoice.

1.verse: Psalm 54 - For the worship leader. A contemplative song of David when his friends, the Ziphites, betrayed him to Saul. Accompanied by strings. This is a lament reflecting the time when David was betrayed to Saul (1 Samuel 23:6–29). It expresses hope that God will save by His name. The name refers to the covenant name given to Moses at Mount Sinai (Exodus 3). We have translated it “the Eternal One.” For the ancients the name of God has power precisely because it embodies the presence of God. To call upon the name was to call upon God to remember His covenant promises and be present in power in order to rescue His people. Liberate me, O God, by the authority of Your name. Vindicate me through Your legendary power.

2.verse: Hear my prayer, O God; let the words of my mouth reach Your sympathetic ear.

3.verse: The truth is, these strangers are rallying against me; cold-blooded men seek to slay me; they have no respect for You. [pause]

4.verse: But see now! God comes to rescue me; the Lord is my valiant supporter.

5.verse: He will repay my enemies for the harm they have done; they are doomed! According to Your faithful promises, silence them.

6.verse: I will sacrifice to You willingly; I will lift Your name by shouts of thanksgiving, O Eternal One, for Your name is good.

7.verse: God has pulled me out from every one of the troubles that encompass me, and I have seen what it means to stand over my enemies in triumph.

1.verse: Psalm 55 - For the worship leader. A contemplative song of David accompanied by strings. Hear me, O God. Tune Your ear to my plea, and do not turn Your face from my prayer.

2.verse: Give me Your attention. Answer these sighs of sorrow; my troubles have made me restless—I groan from anxiety

3.verse: All because of my enemy! Because his voice speaks against me, his wickedness torments me! He casts down misfortune upon me; his anger flares; his grudges grow against me.

4.verse: My heart seizes within my chest; I am in anguish! I am terrified my life could end on any breath.

5.verse: I shiver and shudder in fear; I can’t stop because this horror is just too much.

6.verse: I said, “If only my arms were wings like the dove’s! I would fly away from here and find rest—

7.verse: Yes, I would venture far and weave a nest in the wilderness. [pause]

8.verse: “I would rush to take refuge away from the violent storm and pounding winds.”

9.verse: Throw them off, O Lord. Confuse their speech, and frustrate their plans, for violence and contention are building within the city. I can see it with my own eyes.

10.verse: They plot day and night, scurrying the city walls like rats, trouble and evil lurking everywhere.

11.verse: In the heart of the city, destruction awaits. Oppression and lies swarm the streets, and they will not take leave; no, they will not go.

12.verse: If it were just an enemy sneering at me, I could take it. If it were just someone who has always hated me, treating me like dirt, I’d simply hide away.

13.verse: But it is you! A man like me, my old friend, my companion.

14.verse: We enjoyed sweet conversation, walking together in the house of God among the pressing crowds.

15.verse: Let death sneak up on them, swallow them alive into the pit of death. Why? Because evil stirs in their homes; evil is all around them.

16.verse: But I, I shall call upon God, and by His word, the Eternal shall save me.

17.verse: Evening, morning, and noon I will plead; I will grumble and moan before Him until He hears my voice.

18.verse: And He will rescue my soul, untouched, plucked safely from the battle, despite the many who are warring against me.

19.verse: God, enthroned from ancient times through eternity, will hear my prayers and strike them down. [pause] For they have refused change; they supply their every need and have no fear of God.

20.verse: My friend has become a foe, breaking faith, tearing down peace. He’s betrayed our covenant.

21.verse: Oh, how his pleasant voice is smoother than butter, while his heart is enchanted by war. Oh, how his words are smoother than oil, and yet each is a sword drawn in his hand.

22.verse: Cast your troubles upon the Eternal; His care is unceasing! He will not allow His righteous to be shaken.

23.verse: But You, O God, You will drive them into the lowest pit— Violent, lying people won’t live beyond their middle years. But I place my trust in You.

1.verse: Psalm 56 - For the worship leader. A prayer of David to the tune “Silent Dove in the Distance,” when the Philistine oppressors seized him in Gath. Psalm 56 brings to mind the time when David fled from Saul and sought help from the Philistines, his former enemies (1 Samuel 21:10–15). In his time of panic and fear, David found courage in trusting God to do what could not be done by human power and ingenuity alone. Show mercy to me, O God, because people are crushing me— grinding me down like dirt underfoot—all day long. No matter what I do, I can’t get myself out from under them.

2.verse: My enemies are crushing me, yes all day long, O Highest of High, for many come proud and raise their hands against me.

3.verse: When struck by fear, I let go, depending securely upon You alone.

4.verse: In God—whose word I praise— in God I place my trust. I shall not let fear come in, for what can measly men do to me?

5.verse: All day long they warp my words; all their thoughts against me are mangled by evil.

6.verse: They conspire, then lurk about. They eye my every move, Waiting to steal my very life.

7.verse: Because they are wicked through and through, drag them out. In Your just anger, O God, cast them down!

8.verse: You have taken note of my journey through life, caught each of my tears in Your bottle. But God, are they not also blots on Your book?

9.verse: Then my enemies shall turn back and scatter on the day I call out to You. This I know for certain: God is on my side.

10.verse: In God whose word I praise and in the Eternal whose word I praise—

11.verse: In God I have placed my trust. I shall not let fear come in, for what can measly men do to me?

12.verse: I am bound by Your promise, O God. My life is my offering of thanksgiving to You,

13.verse: For You have saved my soul from the darkness of death, steadied my feet from stumbling So I might continue to walk before God, embraced in the light of the living.

1.verse: Psalm 57 - For the worship leader. A prayer of David to the tune “Do Not Destroy,” when he hid from Saul in a cave. This individual lament refers back to those perilous times when David fled from Saul and hid in caves (1 Samuel 22; 24). David found real security not in the hidden recesses of the caves but in the shadow of God’s wings. Mercy. May Your mercy come to me, O God, for my soul is safe within You, the guardian of my life. I will seek protection in the shade of Your wings until the destruction has passed.

2.verse: I cry out to God, the Most High, to God who always does what is good for me.

3.verse: Out of heaven my rescue comes. He dispatches His mercy and truth And goes after whoever tries to run over me. [pause]

4.verse: I am surrounded by lions; I lie in a den of ravenous beasts. Those around me have spears and arrows for teeth, a sharpened blade for a tongue.

5.verse: O God, be lifted up above the heavens; may Your glory cover the earth.

6.verse: Yet my foes cast a net to catch my feet and bring me to my knees. I am weary from all of this. They dug a pit to snare me but fell into their own trap. [pause]

7.verse: My heart is ready, O God; my heart is ready, And I will sing! Yes, I will sing praise!

8.verse: Wake up, my glory! Wake up, harp and lyre; I will stir the sleepy dawn with praise!

9.verse: I will offer You my thanks, O Lord, before the nations of the world; I will sing of Your greatness no matter where I am.

10.verse: For Your amazing mercy ascends far into the heavens; Your truth rises above the clouds.

11.verse: O God, be lifted up above the heavens; may Your glory cover the earth.

1.verse: Psalm 58 - For the worship leader. A prayer of David to the tune “Do Not Destroy.” Can you, panel of judges, get anything right? When you judge people, do you tell the truth and pursue justice?

2.verse: No, your real selves have been revealed. You have wickedness in your heart, and many people have suffered by your hands.

3.verse: Evildoers are naturally offensive, wayward at birth! They were born telling lies and willfully wandering from the truth.

4.verse: Their bite is painful; their venom is like the deadly poison of a snake; they are like a cobra that closes up its ears

5.verse: To escape the voice of the charmers, no matter how enchanting the spells may be.

6.verse: O God, shatter their teeth in their mouths! Render the young lions harmless; break out their fangs, O Eternal One.

7.verse: Let them run off like the waters of a flood, and though they aim their arrows, let them fly without their heads.

8.verse: Let them melt like a snail that oozes along; may they be like a stillborn that never catches its first breath, never sees the sun.

9.verse: Before your cook pots know the furious flame of a fire of thorns— whether green or burning—He will blow the wicked away.

10.verse: Cheers will rise as the right-living watch Him settle the score, their feet washed in the blood after the onslaught of the wicked.

11.verse: And it will be heard, “Those who seek justice will be rewarded. Indeed, there is a God who brings justice to the earth!”

1.verse: Psalm 59 - For the worship leader. A prayer of David to the tune “Do Not Destroy,” when Saul sent assassins to David’s house. Psalm 59 was inspired by the time there was a plan to kill David that was thwarted by David’s wife, Michal, who was Saul’s own daughter. She warned her husband, lowered him out of a window, and then deceived her father’s officers into believing David was bedridden with illness (1 Samuel 19:11–17). Rescue me! Save me, O my God, from my enemies; set me in a safe place, far above any who come to attack me.

2.verse: Rescue me from those malicious people, and save me from blood-thirsty murderers.

3.verse: They have staked out my life; they are going to ambush me! Those brutes are aligned, ready to attack me For no good cause, my Eternal One. I have not crossed them.

4.verse: I’ve done nothing wrong, yet they rush ahead to start the assault. I beg You to help me; come and see for Yourself!

5.verse: I plead with You, Eternal One, Commander of heavenly armies, True God of Israel, to get up and punish these people; do not let any betrayer off the hook; show no mercy to malicious evildoers! [pause]

6.verse: Treacherous souls return to the city in the evening; they prowl about, howling like dogs.

7.verse: Watch them! Snarling, dribbling their malicious insults. Their words cut loose from their lips like swords, and in their backstabbing they say, “Who’s listening anyway?”

8.verse: But You, O Eternal One, laugh at them; You make fun of all the nations.

9.verse: I will watch for You, for You keep me strong. God, You are my security!

10.verse: My God is one step ahead of me with His mercy; He will show me the victory I desire over my enemies.

11.verse: Don’t wipe them out, or my people may one day forget. Instead, use Your power to scatter and bring them to ruin. O Lord, You are our protection.

12.verse: Sin pours from their mouths, cruel words from their lips. May they be caught in their pride. For their foul curses and lies,

13.verse: devour them with Your wrath, eat them up, leave no one alive. Then people will surely know that the one True God rules over Jacob, even to the far ends of the earth. [pause]

14.verse: Treacherous souls return to the city in the evening; they prowl about, howling like dogs.

15.verse: They search through the city, scavenging for meat as they growl and grumble in dissatisfaction.

16.verse: But me? I will sing of Your strength. I will awake with the sun to sing of Your loving mercy Because in my most troubled hour, You defended me. You were my shelter.

17.verse: I will lift my voice to sing Your praise, O my Strength— for You came to my defense. O God, You have shown me Your loving mercy.

1.verse: Psalm 60 - For the worship leader. A prayer of David after his victory over the Arameans, Joab’s return, and the striking down of 12,000 Edomites in the valley of Salt. A song for instruction to the tune “A Lily Reminds Us.” This is a communal lament recalling David’s battles with Zobah and Naharaim from Aram (Syria) and Joab’s victory over the Edomites (2 Samuel 8). God, You have turned away from us; You have shattered us into a million tiny pieces; You have boiled with anger. Now put us back together, and refresh us with Your mercy.

2.verse: You have made the earth shake; You have cracked it open effortlessly. Heal the fissures in the earth, for it is unsteady.

3.verse: You have caused Your people to suffer; You have provided us with wine that makes us stagger.

4.verse: You have unfurled a banner for those who revere You, a signal to gather in safety out of the enemy’s reach. [pause]

5.verse: So that Your treasured ones may be saved, rescue us with Your right hand, and answer our pleas!

6.verse: God’s voice has been heard in His holy sanctuary: “I will celebrate; I will allocate Shechem and the Succoth Valley to My people.

7.verse: Gilead belongs to Me, and so does Manasseh; Ephraim is the helmet that protects My head; Judah is the scepter through which I rule;

8.verse: Moab is the washpot in which I rinse My feet. I will throw My shoe over Edom in conquest; prepare for My victory, Philistia. Cry out because of Me!”

9.verse: But who will take me into the fortified city? Who will lead me into Edom?

10.verse: Have You not turned Your back on us, O God? Will You stay away and not accompany our armies, O God?

11.verse: Help us against our enemy; we need Your help! It’s useless to trust in the hand of man for liberation.

12.verse: Only through God can we be successful. It is God alone who will defeat our enemies and bring us victory!

1.verse: Psalm 61 - For the worship leader. A song of David accompanied by strings. Hear me, O God, when I cry; listen to my prayer.

2.verse: You are the One I will call when pushed to the edge, when my heart is faint. Shoulder me to the rock above me.

3.verse: For You are my protection, an impenetrable fortress from my enemies.

4.verse: Let me live in Your sanctuary forever; let me find safety in the shadow of Your wings. [pause]

5.verse: You have heard the promises I made, O God. You have laid upon me the legacy due to those who fear Your name.

6.verse: Extend the king’s life, day after day; increase his years for many generations.

7.verse: May he be ever present before God, attended and guarded by Your loyal love and truth.

8.verse: So I will never stop singing Your praise; as long as I live, I will fulfill my promise.

1.verse: Psalm 62 - For the worship leader, Jeduthun. A song of David. My soul quietly waits for the True God alone; my salvation comes from Him.

2.verse: He alone is my rock and my deliverance, my citadel high on the hill; I will not be shaken.

3.verse: How long will you attack a man? How long will all of you strive to crush your prey when he’s like a leaning fence or a wall on the verge of collapse?

4.verse: Their only purpose in life is to knock him down from his prominent position; they love deceit. When others are around, they speak a blessing on someone, but inwardly they are mumbling a curse. [pause]

5.verse: My soul quietly waits for the True God alone because I hope only in Him.

6.verse: He alone is my rock and deliverance, my citadel high on a hill; I will not be shaken.

7.verse: My salvation and my significance depend ultimately on God; the core of my strength, my shelter, is in the True God.

8.verse: Have faith in Him in all circumstances, dear people. Open up your heart to Him; the True God shelters us in His arms. [pause]

9.verse: Human beings disappear like a breath; even people of rank live artificial lives. Their weight is that of a breath in a balance—nothing. Added together, they’re still lighter than air.

10.verse: Do not resort to oppression; resist the temptation of ill-gotten gain. If you achieve wealth, don’t let your heart get attached.

11.verse: The True God spoke this once, and twice I’ve heard: That You, the True God, hold all power;

12.verse: Your love never fails, O Lord, for You pay every person back according to his deeds.

1.verse: Psalm 63 - A song of David while in the wilderness of Judah. O True God, You are my God, the One whom I trust. I seek You with every fiber of my being. In this dry and weary land with no water in sight, my soul is dry and longs for You. My body aches for You, for Your presence.

2.verse: I have seen You in Your sanctuary and have been awed by Your power and glory.

3.verse: Your steadfast love is better than life itself, so my lips will give You all my praise.

4.verse: I will bless You with every breath of my life; I will lift up my hands in praise to Your name.

5.verse: My soul overflows with satisfaction, as when I feast on foods rich in marrow and fat; with excitement in my heart and joy on my lips, I offer You praise.

6.verse: Often at night I lie in bed and remember You, meditating on Your greatness till morning smiles through my window.

7.verse: You have been my constant helper; therefore, I sing for joy under the protection of Your wings.

8.verse: My soul clings to You; Your right hand reaches down and holds me up.

9.verse: But as for those who try to destroy my life, they will descend into eternal shadows, deep beneath the earth.

10.verse: They will fall by the sword, and wild dogs will feast on their corpses.

11.verse: But the king will find his joy in the True God; all who make pledges and invoke His name will celebrate, while the mindless prattle of cheaters and deceivers will be silenced.

1.verse: Psalm 64 - For the worship leader. A song of David. O True God, hear my voice! Listen to my complaint! Guard my life; keep me safe from my enemy’s threats.

2.verse: Hide me from the sinful circle that conspires against me, from the band of rebels out to make trouble,

3.verse: Who sharpen their tongues into swords, who take aim with poisonous words like arrows.

4.verse: They hide in the shadows and shoot at the innocent; they shoot at them without warning and without any fear.

5.verse: They persist in their evil purpose and plan in secret to lay their traps. And they say, “Who will see them?”

6.verse: They plot their offense with precision and say, “Now we have the perfect crime.” The human heart and mind are deep and complex.

7.verse: But without hesitation the True God will shoot at them; His arrow will surely wound them.

8.verse: He will use their very own words to bring them to destruction; all who see will be appalled at what happens to them.

9.verse: Then everyone will fear the True God; they will proclaim His deeds and will reflect upon all He has done.

10.verse: The righteous will delight in the Eternal and will take shelter in Him. All those with an honest heart will glorify Him!

1.verse: Psalm 65 - For the worship leader. A song of David. All will stand in awe to praise You. Praise will sweep through Zion, the Sacred City, O God. Solemn vows uttered to You will now be performed.

2.verse: You hear us pray in words and silence; all humanity comes into Your presence.

3.verse: Injustice overwhelms me! But You forgive our sins, restoring as only You can.

4.verse: You invite us near, drawing us into Your courts—what an honor and a privilege! We feast until we’re full on the goodness of Your house, Your sacred temple made manifest.

5.verse: You leave us breathless when Your awesome works answer us by putting everything right. God of our liberation— You are the hope of all creation, from the far corners of the earth to distant life-giving oceans.

6.verse: With immense power, You erected mountains. Wrapped in strength, You compelled

7.verse: Choppy seas, crashing waves, and crowds of people To sit in astonished silence.

8.verse: Those who inhabit the boundaries of the earth are awed by Your signs, strong and subtle hints of Your indelible presence. Even the dawn and dusk respond to You with joy.

9.verse: You spend time on the good earth, watering and nourishing the networks of the living. God’s river is full of water! By preparing the land, You have provided us grain for nourishment.

10.verse: You are the gentle equalizer: soaking the furrows, smoothing soil’s ridges, Softening sun-baked earth with generous showers, blessing the fruit of the ground.

11.verse: You crown the year with a fruitful harvest; the paths are worn down by carts overflowing with unstoppable growth.

12.verse: Barren desert pastures yield fruit; craggy hills are now dressed for celebration.

13.verse: Meadows are clothed with frolicking flocks of lambs; valleys are covered with a carpet of autumn-harvest grain; the land shouts and sings in joyous celebration.

1.verse: Psalm 66 - For the worship leader. A song. Shout out to God, all the earth. Erupt with joy to the one True God!

2.verse: Sing of the glory due His name! Offer Him the most magnificent praises!

3.verse: Say to God, “All You have done is wondrous and causes fear! Your power is mighty, and Your enemies pretend to submit to You.

4.verse: The entire earth will bow down to worship You and will sing glory-songs to You; they will sing praises to Your name! [pause]

5.verse: Come and witness the True God’s endless works. His miraculous deeds done on behalf of humanity inspire fear.

6.verse: He transformed the sea into dry land; our people passed through the river on foot! Rejoice in Him; celebrate what He did there!

7.verse: By His great might, He rules forever; His eyes watch over all the nations, so no one should go up against Him. [pause]

8.verse: Everyone, bless our True God! Let praise-filled voices be heard near and far—at home and on foreign soil!

9.verse: Praise the One who gives us life and keeps us safe, who does not allow us to stumble in the darkness.

10.verse: For You have put us to the test, O God; You have refined us as silver is refined.

11.verse: You trapped us with a snare; You have laid upon our backs a heavy burden.

12.verse: You allowed us to be conquered and let our enemies run over us. We journeyed through dangers, through fire and flood, But You led us finally to a safe place, a land rich and abundant.

13.verse: I will come into Your temple with burnt offerings; I will fulfill my promises to You—

14.verse: The oaths that parted my lips and were promises my mouth freely made when I was suffering and in anguish.

15.verse: I will bring You my sacrifices—plump beasts and the sweet smoke of consecrated rams— I will also offer You bulls and goats. [pause]

16.verse: Come and listen, everyone who reveres the True God, and I will tell you what He has done for me.

17.verse: I cried out to Him with my mouth, and I praised Him with my tongue.

18.verse: If I entertain evil in my heart, the Lord will not hear me.

19.verse: But surely God has heard me; He has paid attention to the urgency of my request.

20.verse: May the True God be blessed, for He did not turn away from my prayer nor did He hold back His loyal love from me.

1.verse: Psalm 67 - For the worship leader. A song accompanied by strings. Psalm 67 echoes the priestly blessing (Numbers 6:24–26) and invites all nations to join in praise to the one True God. May God pour His grace and blessings into us and turn His face to shine His light on us. [pause]

2.verse: So all those on earth will learn to follow Your way and see Your saving power come to redeem all nations.

3.verse: May all people live to praise You, Our True God; may all come to praise You.

4.verse: May all nations celebrate together, singing joy-filled songs of praise to You because You judge the people fairly and give guidance to all the nations of the earth. [pause]

5.verse: May the people praise You with their whole hearts, O God; may every man, woman, and child on the earth praise You.

6.verse: The land has supplied a bountiful harvest, and the True God, our God, has poured out His blessings to us all.

7.verse: God is the source of our blessings; may every corner of the earth respect and revere Him.

1.verse: Psalm 68 - For the worship leader. A song of David. Psalm 68 is a hymn describing God as a Divine Warrior, marching from Sinai through the wilderness to make His home in Jerusalem. May the True God rise up and show Himself; may those who are united against Him be dispersed, while the people who hate Him run away at the sight of Him.

2.verse: As smoke disappears when it is blown by the wind, may You blow away Your enemies forever. As wax melts in the presence of fire, may the wicked heart melt away in God’s presence.

3.verse: But may those who are righteous rejoice in the presence of the True God—so may they be glad and rejoice. Yes, let them celebrate with joy!

4.verse: Sing songs of praise to the name that belongs to the True God! Let your voices ring out in songs of praise to Him, the One who rides through the deserted places. His name is the Eternal; celebrate in His glorious presence.

5.verse: The True God who inhabits sacred space is a father to the fatherless, a defender of widows.

6.verse: He makes a home for those who are alone. He frees the prisoners and leads them to prosper. Yet those who rebel against Him live in the barren land without His blessings and prosperity.

7.verse: O True God, when You led Your enslaved people from Egypt, when You journeyed with us through the wilderness, [pause]

8.verse: The whole world trembled! The sky poured down rain at the power of Your presence; even Mount Sinai trembled in Your presence, the presence of the True God, the God of Israel.

9.verse: You sent a heavy downpour to soak the ground, O True God. You refreshed the land—the land Your people would inherit—when it was parched and dry.

10.verse: Your covenant people made their homes in the land, and because You are so good, You provided for those crushed by poverty, O True God.

11.verse: The Lord gives the word; there are very many women ready to tell the good news:

12.verse: “Kings who lead the armies are on the run! They are on the run! And the woman who stays at home is ready, too, ready to enjoy the treasures that they’ve left behind!”

13.verse: When they lay down among the campfires and open the saddlebags, imagine what they’ll find— a beautiful dove, its wings covered with silver, its feathers a shimmering gold.

14.verse: When the Almighty scattered the kings from that place, it was snowing in Zalmon.

15.verse: O Mount Bashan, you mighty mountain of the True God; mountain of many peaks, O Mount Bashan.

16.verse: Why are you so jealous, O mountain of many peaks, when you look at the mountain the True God has chosen as His dwelling place? The Eternal will surely abide on Mount Zion forever.

17.verse: The chariots of God are innumerable; there are thousands upon thousands of them. The Lord is in their midst, just as He was at Mount Sinai. He has come into the holy place.

18.verse: When You ascended the sacred mountain, with Your prisoners in tow, Your captives in chains, You sat in triumph receiving gifts from men, Even from those who rebel against You, so that You, the Eternal God, might take up residence there.

19.verse: Blessed be the Lord who carries our heavy loads every day, the True God who is our salvation. [pause]

20.verse: We know our God is the God who delivers us, and the Eternal, the Lord, is the One who saves us from the grip of death.

21.verse: The True God will certainly shatter the skulls of those who oppose Him; He’ll smash the hairy head of the man who continues on his sinful ways.

22.verse: The Lord said, “I will bring the enemy back from Bashan. I will bring them back from the deepest parts of the sea,

23.verse: So that you may plant your feet in their blood and your dogs may lick up their portion of the foe.”

24.verse: The solemn march in Your honor, O True God, has come into view; the march that celebrates my God, my King, has come into the sanctuary.

25.verse: The singers went first, and the musicians came last between rows of girls who played tambourines.

26.verse: Come, let us gather to bless the True God and to praise the Eternal, He who is the fountain of Israel, the source of our life!

27.verse: Look! There are the rulers of Benjamin, the youngest in the lead. A great crowd follows The princes of Judah, the princes of Zebulun, the princes of Naphtali.

28.verse: [Your God is the One who has given you strength]; show Your power, O True God, as You have done for us.

29.verse: Because of Your magnificent temple in Jerusalem, many kings will line up to bring You gifts.

30.verse: Reprimand the beasts in the tall grass, the herds of bulls that are with the people’s calves, Trampling over the pieces of silver. He has driven out the people who love to be at war.

31.verse: Ambassadors will come from Egypt; the people of Ethiopia will reach out their hands to the one True God.

32.verse: Let all the kingdoms of the earth sing to the True God. Sing songs of praise to the Lord. [pause]

33.verse: To Him who rides high up beyond the heavens, which have been since ancient times, watch and listen. His voice speaks, and it is powerful and strong.

34.verse: Attribute power to the one True God; His royal splendor is evident over Israel, and His power courses through the clouds.

35.verse: O True God, You are awesome from the holy place where You dwell. The True God of Israel Himself grants strength and power to His people. Blessed be our God!

1.verse: Psalm 69 - For the worship leader. A song of David to the tune “Lilies.” This Davidic lament complains to God of enemies, false witnesses, insults, abandonment by friends and family, and even poisoning. Early Christians interpreted this psalm prophetically in order to understand Jesus’ experience in His suffering and death on the cross. Reach down for me, True God; deliver me. The waters have risen to my neck; I am going down!

2.verse: My feet are swallowed in this murky bog; I am sinking—there is no sturdy ground. I am in the deep; the floods are crashing in!

3.verse: I am weary of howling; my throat is scratched dry. I still look for my God even though my eyes fail.

4.verse: My enemies despise me without any cause; they outnumber the hairs on my head. They torment me with their power; they have absolutely no reason to hate me. Now I am set to pay for crimes I have never committed!

5.verse: O True God, my foolish ways are plain before You; my mistakes—no, nothing can be hidden from You.

6.verse: Don’t let Your hopeful followers face disgrace because of me, O Lord, Eternal One, Commander of heaven’s armies; Don’t let Your seekers be shamed on account of me, O True God of Israel.

7.verse: I have been mocked when I stood up for You; I cower, shamefaced.

8.verse: You know my brothers and sisters? They now reject me—they act as if I never existed. I’m like a stranger to my own family.

9.verse: And here’s why: I am consumed with You, completely devoted to protecting Your house; when they insult You, they insult me.

10.verse: When I mourn and discipline my soul by fasting, they deride me.

11.verse: And when I put on sackcloth, they mock me.

12.verse: Those who sit at the gate gossip about me; I am shamed by the slurred songs of drunkards.

13.verse: But, Eternal One, I just pray the time is right that You would hear me. And, True God, because You are enduring love, that You would answer. In Your faithfulness, please, save me.

14.verse: Pluck me from this murky bog; don’t let it pull me down! Pull me from this rising water; take me away from my enemies to dry land.

15.verse: Don’t let the flood take me under or let me, Your servant, be swallowed into the deep or let the yawning pit seal me in!

16.verse: O Eternal One, hear me. Answer me. For Your enduring love is good comfort; in Your great mercy, turn toward me.

17.verse: Yes, shine Your face upon me, Your servant; put an end to my anguish—don’t wait another minute.

18.verse: Come near; rescue me! Set me free from my enemies.

19.verse: You know all my opponents; You see them, see the way they treat me— humiliating me with insults, trying to disgrace me.

20.verse: All this ridicule has broken my heart, killed my spirit. I searched for sympathy, and I came up empty. I looked for supporters, but there was no one.

21.verse: Even more, they gave me poison for my food and offered me only sour vinegar to drink.

22.verse: Let them be ambushed at the dinner table, caught in a trap when they least expect it.

23.verse: Cloud their vision so they cannot see; make their bodies shake, their knees knock in terror.

24.verse: Pour out Your fiery wrath upon them! Make a clean sweep; engulf them with Your flaming fury.

25.verse: May their camps be bleak with not one left in any tent.

26.verse: Because they have persecuted the one You have struck, add insult to those whom You have wounded.

27.verse: Compound their sins; don’t let them off the hook! Keep them from entering into Your mercy.

28.verse: Blot out their names from Your book of life so they will not be recorded alongside those who are upright before You.

29.verse: I am living in pain; I’m suffering, so save me, True God, and keep me safe in troubled times!

30.verse: The name of the True God will be my song, an uplifting tune of praise and thanksgiving!

31.verse: My praise will please the Eternal more than if I were to sacrifice an ox or the finest bull. (Horns, hooves, and all!)

32.verse: Those who humbly serve will see and rejoice! All you seekers-after-God will revive your souls!

33.verse: The Eternal listens to the prayers of the poor and has regard for His people held in bondage.

34.verse: All God’s creation: join together in His praise! All heaven, all earth, all seas, all creatures of the ocean deep!

35.verse: The True God will save Zion and rebuild the cities of Judah So that His servants may own it and live there once again.

36.verse: Their children and children’s children shall have it as their inheritance, and those who love His name will live in it.

1.verse: Psalm 70 - For the worship leader. A song of David for remembering. O God, hurry to save me; Eternal One, hurry to my side.

2.verse: For those who seek to kill me, God, may they burn in disgrace and humiliation! Repulse the attacks; ridicule the efforts of those taking pleasure in my pain.

3.verse: I hear their taunts: “Nah, nah, nah . . . .” Let those hecklers fall back upon their brays—ashamed and confused—

4.verse: But let those who pursue You celebrate and have joy because of You. And let the song of those who love Your saving grace never cease: “God is great!”

5.verse: But I am poor and in serious need, so hurry to my side, God, Because You are my helper, my liberator. Eternal One, please don’t wait.

1.verse: Psalm 71 - I have found shelter in You, Eternal One; I count on You to shield me always from humiliation and disgrace.

2.verse: Rescue and save me in Your justice. Turn Your ear to me, and hurry to deliver me from my enemies.

3.verse: Be my rock of refuge where I can always hide. You have given the order to keep me safe; You are my solid ground—my rock and my fortress.

4.verse: Save me from the power of sinful people, O my God, from the grip of unjust and cruel men.

5.verse: For You are my hope, Eternal One; You, Lord, have been the source of my confidence since I was young.

6.verse: I have leaned upon You since I came into this world; I have relied on You since You took me safely from my mother’s body, So I will ever praise You.

7.verse: Many find me a mystery, but You are my rock and my shelter—my soul’s asylum.

8.verse: My mouth overflows with praise to You and proclaims Your magnificence all day long.

9.verse: Do not set me aside when I am old; do not abandon me when I am worn out.

10.verse: For my enemies often voice evil against me; those who desire to kill me plot together in secret.

11.verse: They say, “God has abandoned him; let’s go after him right now and seize him. There’s no one around to rescue him.”

12.verse: God, stay close by me. Come quick, O my God, and help me!

13.verse: May my enemies be covered in shame and then die; may those who seek to harm me be overwhelmed with contempt and disgrace.

14.verse: But I will keep hope alive, and my praise to You will grow exponentially.

15.verse: I will bear witness to Your merciful acts; throughout the day I will speak of all the ways You deliver, although, I admit, I do not know the entirety of either.

16.verse: I will come with stories of Your great acts, my Lord, the Eternal. I will remind them of Your justice, only Yours.

17.verse: You have taught me since I was young, O God, and I still proclaim the wonderful things You have done.

18.verse: Now as I grow old and my hair turns gray, I ask that You not abandon me, O God. Allow me to share with the generation to come about Your power; Let me speak about Your strength and wonders to all those yet to be born.

19.verse: God, Your justice stretches to the heavens, You who have done mighty things! Who is like You, O God?

20.verse: You have made me see hard times: I’ve experienced many miserable days, but You will restore me again. You will raise me up from the deep pit.

21.verse: You will greatly increase my status and be my comfort once again.

22.verse: I will praise You with music played on a harp because You have been faithful, O my God. I will sing praises to You with the lyre, O Holy One of Israel.

23.verse: I will shout for joy as I sing Your praises; my soul will celebrate because You have rescued me.

24.verse: All day long I will declare how Your justice saved me, for those who have plotted to bring me harm are now ashamed and humiliated.

1.verse: Psalm 72 - A song of Solomon. True God, bestow Your honest judgments upon the king and anoint the king’s son with Your righteousness.

2.verse: May he be honest and fair in his judgments over Your people and offer justice to the burdened and suffering.

3.verse: Under his reign, may this land of mountains and hills know peace and experience justice for all the people.

4.verse: May the king offer justice to the burdened and suffering, rescue the poor and needy, and demolish the oppressor!

5.verse: [May the people fear You] for as long as the sun shines, as long as the moon rises in the night sky, throughout the generations.

6.verse: May the king be like the refreshing rains, which fall upon fields of freshly mown grass— like showers that cool and nourish the earth.

7.verse: May good and honest people flourish for as long as he reigns, and may peace fill the land until the moon no longer rises.

8.verse: May the king rule from one sea to the next, and may his rule extend from the Euphrates River to the far reaches of the earth.

9.verse: Let the desert wanderers bow down before him and his enemies lay prostrate and taste the dirt.

10.verse: Let the kings of Tarshish and the island kings shower him with gifts And the kings of Sheba and Seba bring him presents as well.

11.verse: Let every king on earth bow down before him and every nation be in his service.

12.verse: For he will rescue the needy when they ask for help! He will save the burdened and come to the aid of those who have no other help.

13.verse: He offers compassion to the weak and the poor; he will help and protect the lives of the needy!

14.verse: He will liberate them from the fierce sting of persecution and violence; in his eyes, their blood is precious.

15.verse: May he live a long, long time and the gold of Sheba be given to him. May the people constantly lift up prayers for him, and may they call upon God to bless him always.

16.verse: Let grain grow plentifully in this land of promise, let it sway in the breeze on the hilltops, let it grow strong as do the cedars of Lebanon, Woven throughout the psalms are songs describing and praising those anointed as kings over God’s people. Psalm 2, one of the introductory psalms, describes the king as the son of God, the ruler of nations, and the anointed one. During the monarchical period in Israel, psalms like these were tied to the kings themselves, idealizing them as perfectly just and righteous and victorious. But during the exile, God’s exiled people longed for freedom and the implications of these songs began to change. Many Jews began to interpret these psalms as referring to a coming ruler, a Davidic king who would usher in an eternal kingdom and perfect peace. This hope was realized in Jesus. So this is why the earliest followers of Jesus went back to the psalms again and again. They found within many of the psalms, the story of Jesus anticipated and celebrated. And may those who live in the city bloom and flourish just as the grass of the fields and meadows.

17.verse: May his name live on forever and his reputation grow for as long as the sun gives light. May people from all nations find in him a blessing; may all peoples declare him blessed.

18.verse: May the Eternal God, the God of Israel, be blessed, for He alone works miracles and wonders!

19.verse: May His glorious name be blessed forever and the whole earth be filled with His eternal glory! Amen. Amen.

20.verse: The prayers of King David, Jesse’s son, are ended.

1.verse: Book Three - Many of the psalms in Book Three (Psalms 73–89) are attributed to Asaph. He was a Levite musician appointed by David to lead the worship that surrounded the covenant chest in the congregation tent (1 Chronicles 16:4–6). Asaph and his descendants continued this work through much of Israel’s history, specifically when Solomon dedicated the temple (2 Chronicles 5:12), when Josiah revived the worship of the Eternal One in Jerusalem (2 Chronicles 35:15), and when Ezra and Nehemiah dedicated the wall around Jerusalem (Nehemiah 12:35). The psalms attributed to Asaph were liturgical, that is, they were chanted or sung as a part of the regular worship of God in the temple by the priests, Levites, and perhaps other worshipers too. Whether songs of lament, requests for guidance, or pleas for mercy, these psalms were sung in the one place God would hear them best—at His temple—the nexus between heaven and earth. Psalm 73 - A song of Asaph. Truly God is good to His people, Israel, to those with pure hearts.

2.verse: Though I know this is true, I almost lost my footing; yes, my steps were on slippery ground.

3.verse: You see, there was a time when I envied arrogant men and thought, “The wicked look pretty happy to me.”

4.verse: For they seem to live carefree lives, free of suffering; their bodies are strong and healthy.

5.verse: They don’t know trouble as we do; they are not plagued with problems as the rest of us are.

6.verse: They’ve got pearls of pride strung around their necks; they clothe their bodies with violence.

7.verse: They have so much more than enough. Their eyes bulge because they are so fat with possessions. They have more than their hearts could have ever imagined.

8.verse: There is nothing sacred, and no one is safe. Vicious sarcasm drips from their lips; they bully and threaten to crush their enemies.

9.verse: They even mock God as if He were not above; their arrogant tongues boast throughout the earth; they feel invincible.

10.verse: Even God’s people turn and are carried away by them; they watch and listen, yet find no fault in them.

11.verse: You will hear them say, “How can the True God possibly know anyway? He’s not even here. So how can the Most High have any knowledge of what happens here?”

12.verse: Let me tell you what I know about the wicked: they are comfortably at rest while their wealth is growing and growing.

13.verse: Oh, let this not be me! It seems I have scrubbed my heart to keep it clean and washed my hands in innocence. And for what? Nothing.

14.verse: For all day long, I am being punished, each day awakening to stern chastisement.

15.verse: If I had said to others these kinds of things about the plight of God’s good people, then I know I would have betrayed the next generation.

16.verse: Trying to solve this mystery on my own exhausted me; I couldn’t bear to look at it any further.

17.verse: So I took my questions to the True God, and in His sanctuary I realized something so chilling and final: their lives have a deadly end.

18.verse: Because You have certainly set the wicked upon a slippery slope, You’ve set them up to slide to their destruction.

19.verse: And they won’t see it coming. It will happen so fast: first, a flash of terror, and then desolation.

20.verse: It is like a dream from which someone awakes. You will wake up, Lord, and loathe what has become of them.

21.verse: You see, my heart overflowed with bitterness and cynicism; I felt as if someone stabbed me in the back.

22.verse: But I didn’t know the truth; I have been acting like a stupid animal toward You.

23.verse: But look at this: You are still holding my right hand; You have been all along.

24.verse: Even though I was angry and hard-hearted, You gave me good advice; when it’s all over, You will receive me into Your glory.

25.verse: For all my wanting, I don’t have anyone but You in heaven. There is nothing on earth that I desire other than You.

26.verse: I admit how broken I am in body and spirit, but God is my strength, and He will be mine forever.

27.verse: It will happen: whoever shuns You will be silenced forever; You will bring an end to all who refuse to be true to You.

28.verse: But the closer I am to You, my God, the better because life with You is good. O Lord, the Eternal, You keep me safe— I will tell everyone what You have done.

1.verse: Psalm 74 - A contemplative song of Asaph. This lament was written shortly after the Babylonian destruction of Jerusalem and the temple in 586 B.C. Now in exile and separated from God, His city, and His land, the people of God experience pain that is palpable. O True God, why have You turned Your back on us and abandoned us forever? Why is Your anger seething and Your wrath smoldering against the sheep of Your pasture?

2.verse: Remember the congregation of people You acquired long ago, the tribe which You redeemed to be Your very own. Remember Mount Zion, where You have chosen to live!

3.verse: Come, direct Your attention to Your sanctuary; our enemy has demolished everything and left it in complete ruin.

4.verse: Your enemies roared like lions in Your sacred chamber; they have claimed it with their own standards as signs.

5.verse: They acted like lumberjacks swinging their axes to cut down a stand of trees.
