6.verse: They hacked up all the beautifully carved items, smashed them to splinters with their axes and hammers.

7.verse: They have burned Your sanctuary to the ground; they have desecrated the place where Your holy name lived in honor;

8.verse: They have plotted in their hearts, “We will crush them and bring them to their knees!” Then they scorched all of the places in the land where the True God met His people.

9.verse: We no longer receive signs, there are no more prophets who remain, and not one of us knows how long this situation will last.

10.verse: O True God, how much longer will the enemy mock us? Will this insult continue against You forever?

11.verse: Why do You stand by and do nothing? Unleash Your power and finish them off!

12.verse: Even so, the True God is my King from long ago, bringing salvation to His people throughout the land.

13.verse: You have divided the sea with Your power; You shattered the skulls of the creatures of the sea;

14.verse: You smashed the heads of Leviathan and fed his remains to the people of the desert.

15.verse: You broke open the earth and springs burst forth and streams filled the crevices; You dried up the great rivers.

16.verse: The day and the night are both Yours— You fashioned the sun, moon, and all the lights that pierce the darkness.

17.verse: You have arranged the earth, set all its boundaries; You are the Architect of the seasons: summer and winter.

18.verse: Eternal One, do not forget that the enemy has taunted You and a company of fools has rejected Your name.

19.verse: We are Your precious turtledoves; don’t surrender our souls to the wild beasts. Do not forget the lives of Your poor, afflicted, and brokenhearted ones forever.

20.verse: Be mindful of Your covenant with us, for the dark corners of the land are filled with pockets of violence.

21.verse: Do not allow the persecuted to return without honor; may the poor, wounded, and needy sing praises to You; may they bring glory to Your name!

22.verse: O True God, rise up and defend Your cause; remember how the foolish man insults You every hour of the day.

23.verse: Do not forget the voices of Your enemies, the commotion and chaos of Your foes, which continually grow.

1.verse: Psalm 75 - For the worship leader. A song of Asaph to the tune “Do Not Destroy.” We thank You, O True God. Our souls are overflowing with thanks! Your name is near; Your people remember and tell of Your marvelous works and wonders.

2.verse: You say, “At the time that I choose, I will judge and do so fairly.

3.verse: When the earth and everyone living upon it spin into chaos, I am the One who stabilizes and supports it.” [pause]

4.verse: “I discipline the arrogant by telling them, ‘No more bragging.’ I discipline the wicked by saying, ‘Do not raise your horn to demonstrate your power.

5.verse: Do not thrust your horn into the air, issuing a challenge, and never speak with insolence when you address Me.’”

6.verse: There is no one on earth who can raise up another to grant honor, not from the east or the west, not from the desert. There is no one. God is the only One.

7.verse: God is the only Judge. He is the only One who can ruin or redeem a man.

8.verse: For the Eternal holds a full cup of wine in His hand— a chalice well stirred and foaming full of wrath. He pours the cup out, and all wicked people of the earth drink it up—every drop of it!

9.verse: But I will tell of His great deeds forever. I will sing praises to Jacob’s True God.

10.verse: I will cut off the horns of strength raised by the wicked, but I will lift up the horns of strength of the righteous.

1.verse: Psalm 76 - For the worship leader. A song of Asaph accompanied by strings. This song of Asaph praises Jerusalem as God’s earthly home and celebrates His victory there over enemies, where in the end “He squashes the arrogant spirit of the rulers.” The One known in Judah is the True God; in Israel, His name is great.

2.verse: He has made Salem His home; indeed, He rests in Zion.

3.verse: There He destroyed the instruments of war: flaming arrows, shields, and swords. [pause]

4.verse: You rise and shine like the dawn. You are more majestic than the mountains where game runs wild.

5.verse: The strong-hearted enemies were plundered; they were buried in slumber. Even the noble warriors could not raise a hand to stop You.

6.verse: O True God of Jacob, with just Your rebuke both horse and rider fell into a deep sleep.

7.verse: You are feared; yes, You. And who can stand before You when Your anger flares?

8.verse: You decreed judgment from the heavens. The earth heard it and was petrified with fear, completely still,

9.verse: When the True God arose for judgment to deliver all the meek of the earth. [pause]

10.verse: For the wrath of man will end in praise of You, and whatever wrath is left You will wrap around Yourself like a belt.

11.verse: Make vows to the Eternal your God, and do all you promised; Let all the nations around you bring gifts to the God who arouses fear and awe.

12.verse: He squashes the arrogant spirit of the rulers and inspires fear in the hearts of the kings of the earth.

1.verse: Psalm 77 - For the worship leader, Jeduthun. A song of Asaph. I cry up to heaven, “My God, True God,” and He hears.

2.verse: In my darkest days, I seek the Lord. Through the night, my hands are raised up, stretched out, waiting; And though they do not grow tired, my soul is uneasy.

3.verse: I remember the True God and become distraught. I think about Him, and my spirit becomes weak. [pause]

4.verse: You hold my eyes wide open. I am troubled beyond words.

5.verse: My mind drifts to thoughts of yesterdays and yesteryears.

6.verse: I call to mind my music; it keeps me company at night. Together with my heart I contemplate; my spirit searches, wondering, questioning:

7.verse: “What will the Lord do? Reject us for good? Will He never show us His favor again?

8.verse: Has His loyal love finally worn down? Have His promises reached an end?

9.verse: Has the True God forgotten how to be gracious? In His anger, has He withdrawn His compassion?” [pause]

10.verse: “I can’t help but be distraught,” I said, “for the power of the Most High that was once for us is now against us.”

11.verse: I will remember the actions the Eternal has taken, reminisce on Your ancient wonders.

12.verse: I will reflect on all of Your work; indeed, I will study all You have performed.

13.verse: O God, Your way is so different, so distinct, so divine. No other god compares with our God.

14.verse: You, God, and Your works evoke wonder. You have proved Your strength to the nations.

15.verse: You used Your great power to release Your people: with a strong arm, You freed Jacob’s children, and Joseph’s. [pause]

16.verse: The waters saw You, O True God. The seas saw You and swelled in sorrow. Even the deep trembled.

17.verse: Water poured from the clouds, and the sky boomed out in response as Your arrows of lightning flashed this way and that.

18.verse: The sound of Your thunder whirled within the wind as Your lightning lit up the world. Yes, the whole earth trembled and shook.

19.verse: Your way ran through the sea, Your path cut through great waters, and still no one can spot Your footprints.

20.verse: You led Your people as a flock tended by the hands of Moses and Aaron.

1.verse: Psalm 78 - A contemplative song of Asaph. O my people, listen to me! Hear my instruction; soak up every word of what I am about to tell you.

2.verse: I will open my mouth in parables; I will speak of ancient mysteries—

3.verse: Things that we have heard about, things that we have known, things which our ancestors declared to us again and again.

4.verse: We will not keep these things secret from their children; rather, we will tell the coming generation All about the praise that is due to the Eternal One. We will tell them all about His strength, power, and wonders.

5.verse: He gave His holy law to Jacob, His teaching to the people of Israel, Which He instructed our fathers to pass down to their children

6.verse: So that the coming generation would know them by heart, even the children who are not yet born, So that they might one day stand up and teach them to their children,

7.verse: tell them to put their confidence and hope in God, And never forget the wondrous things He has done. They should obey His commandments always

8.verse: And avoid following in the footsteps of their parents, a hard-headed and rebellious generation— A generation of uncultivated hearts, whose spirits were unfaithful to God.

9.verse: The sons of Ephraim were master archers, armed with all the necessary equipment, yet when the battle hour arrived, they ran away.

10.verse: They were not loyal to their covenant with God; they turned away and refused to walk in it;

11.verse: They did not remember all the wondrous things He had done, even the great miracles He had revealed to them.

12.verse: He did miraculous things in the presence of their ancestors as they made their way out of Egypt, through the fields of Zoan.

13.verse: He split the sea and made them pass through it; He made the waters to rise, forming a wall of water.

14.verse: Every day He led them with a cloud; every night, with a fiery light.

15.verse: He cracked open rocks in the wilderness and provided them with all the water they needed, as plentiful as the depths of the ocean.

16.verse: He caused streams to burst forth from the rock, waters to rush in like a river.

17.verse: Even after witnessing all of these miracles, they still chose to sin against God, to act against the will of the Most High in the desert!

18.verse: They tested God in their stubborn hearts by demanding whatever food they happened to be craving.

19.verse: Then they challenged God: “Can God fill a table with food in the middle of the desert?

20.verse: He split open the rock, and water gushed out; streams and rivers were overflowing! But can He also provide us with bread? Can He supply meat to His sons and daughters?”

21.verse: When the Eternal heard these words, He was furious; His fiery anger erupted against Jacob; His wrath grew against Israel.

22.verse: This all happened because they did not trust God; they did not have faith in His power to save them.

23.verse: Nevertheless, He gave instructions to the clouds in the sky and swung open heaven’s doors;

24.verse: He showered them with manna to soothe their hungry bellies and provided them with the bread of heaven.

25.verse: (In that day mortals ate the bread of heavenly messengers.) God provided them with plenty of food.

26.verse: He stirred up the east wind and blew it through the sky. With His might, He whipped the south wind into a storm;

27.verse: Like dust from the sky, He caused meat to fall on them. Birds, like sand on the seashore, fell to the earth.

28.verse: They landed all about the camp, all around their tents.

29.verse: God’s people feasted on the food-blessings, and their stomachs were filled; He gave them exactly what they desired.

30.verse: But before their bellies were soothed, while their mouths were still full of food,

31.verse: God’s wrath came at them like a tidal wave and swallowed some of the bravest, strongest among them and quieted the youth of Israel.

32.verse: Even after all this, they continued to sin and still did not trust in Him or in the incredible things He did.

33.verse: So He abruptly ended their time; they vanished like a breath; He ended their years suddenly, with terror.

34.verse: After He took some of their lives, those left turned back and sought God wholeheartedly.

35.verse: After all they had endured, they remembered that God, the Most High, was their Rock, their Redeemer,

36.verse: But even then they tried to deceive Him with their words and fool Him with a web of lies.

37.verse: They were not consistently faithful to Him, and they were untrue to their covenant with Him.

38.verse: Yet by His great compassion, He forgave them and decided not to put an end to them. Most of the time, He held back His anger and did not unleash His wrath against them.

39.verse: He was mindful that they were human, frail and fleeting, like a wind that touches one’s skin for a moment, then vanishes.

40.verse: Oh, how often they disobeyed Him in the wilderness and frustrated Him during their time in the desert!

41.verse: Over and over again, they tested God’s patience and caused great pain for Israel’s Holy One.

42.verse: They failed to be mindful of His great strength. They forgot all about the day He saved them from the enemy,

43.verse: When He displayed all sorts of signs and wonders in Egypt, and all the amazing things He did in the region of Zoan

44.verse: When He transformed their rivers into blood so that they could not drink from their streams.

45.verse: He sent armies of flies to bite and torment them and hordes of frogs to ruin and devastate them;

46.verse: He handed over all of their crops to grasshoppers and the fruit of all their labor to locusts;

47.verse: He sent violent hailstorms, which smashed all their vines, and ruined their sycamore-fig trees with biting frost.

48.verse: He handed over all of their cattle to the hailstorms as well and struck all their herds with lightning.

49.verse: He poured His burning wrath upon them— anger, resentment, and trouble— sending a company of heavenly warriors to destroy them.

50.verse: He carved out a road for His wrath; He did not spare any from the sting of death but handed them over to the fangs of the plague.

51.verse: He killed all the firstborn of Egypt, the first products of their manhood in the tents of Ham, the Egyptians’ ancestor.

52.verse: But then He guided His people like sheep to safety and led them like a flock into the desert to freedom;

53.verse: He took them on a safe route so that they would not be afraid, and He allowed the hungry sea to swallow all of their enemies.

54.verse: He led them to His sacred land— to this holy hill, which He had won by the power of His right hand.

55.verse: He forced out the other nations which were living there before them, and He redistributed the lands as an inheritance to His people; He settled the tribes and families of Israel peaceably in their tents.

56.verse: Even after all this, they disobeyed the Most High God and tested His patience and did not live by His commands.

57.verse: Rather, they regressed to their fathers’ ways and lived faithlessly—disloyal traitors! They were as undependable and untrustworthy as a defective bow,

58.verse: For they triggered His wrath by setting up high places, altars to strange gods in His land; they aroused His jealousy by bowing down to idols in the shadow of His presence.

59.verse: God boiled with wrath when He witnessed what they were doing; He totally rejected Israel.

60.verse: He deserted His own sanctuary at Shiloh, the tent where He had lived in the midst of His people.

61.verse: He handed His strength over to captivity; He put His splendor under the enemy’s control.

62.verse: He handed His people over to the sword, and He was filled with anger toward His chosen ones; He was burning with wrath!

63.verse: A great fire consumed all the young men, and the virgin girls were without the joy of their wedding songs.

64.verse: Priests met their doom by the blade of a sword, and widows had no tears to cry; they could not weep.

65.verse: Then the Lord awoke like a man who has been asleep, like a warrior who has been overcome with wine.

66.verse: He forced all His enemies back; He defeated them, weighing them down with everlasting disgrace.

67.verse: He even rejected the tent of Joseph as His home and showed no favor toward the tribe of Ephraim.

68.verse: Instead, He favored the tribe of Judah— Mount Zion, the place He adored.

69.verse: He built His sanctuary like the mountain heights; like the earth, He created it to last forever.

70.verse: He chose His servant David, and called Him out of the sheep pastures.

71.verse: From caring for the ewes, who gently nurse their young, He called him to shepherd His people Jacob and to look after Israel, His inheritance.

72.verse: David shepherded them with the honor and integrity of his heart; he led them in wisdom with strong and skillful hands.

1.verse: Psalm 79 - A song of Asaph. O God, the nations around us have raided the land that belongs to You; they have defiled Your holy house and crushed Jerusalem to a heap of ruins.

2.verse: Your servants are dead; birds of the air swoop down to pick at their remains. Scavengers of the earth eat what is left of Your saints.

3.verse: The enemy poured out their blood; it flowed like water all over Jerusalem, and there is no one left, no one to bury what remains of them.

4.verse: The surrounding peoples taunt us. We are nothing but a joke to them, people to be ridiculed.

5.verse: The Book of Psalms records both the highs and lows in the lives of God’s covenant people. Psalm 79 is an example of a communal lament after the destruction of Jerusalem and the loss of God’s temple. Songs like these address God with a complaint resulting from some sort of national tragedy. Communal laments share a common structure. First, the singers address God and tell Him of their problems. Second, they beg Him for help and express trust that He will answer them, often remembering how He has saved Israel in the past. Finally, the singers promise to praise God once He has resolved their problem. The specifics of the situation determine the thrust of the song. Communal laments are often the people’s poetic and practical response to their perception of God’s inaction in their affairs. How long can this go on, O Eternal One? Will You stay angry at us forever? Your jealousy burning like wildfire?

6.verse: Flood these outsiders with Your wrath— they have no knowledge of You! Drown the kingdoms of this world that call on false gods and not on Your name.

7.verse: For these nations devoured Jacob, consumed him, and turned his home into a wasteland.

8.verse: Do not hold the sins of our ancestors against us, but send Your compassion to meet us quickly, God. We are in deep despair.

9.verse: Help us, O God who saves us, to the honor and glory of Your name. Pull us up, deliver us, and forgive our sins, for Your name’s sake.

10.verse: Don’t give these people any reason to ask, “Where is their God?” Avenge the blood spilled by Your servants. Put it on display among the nations before our very eyes.

11.verse: May the deep groans and wistful sighs of the prisoners reach You, and by Your great power, save those condemned to die.

12.verse: Pay back each of our invaders personally, seven times for the shame they heaped on You, O Lord!

13.verse: Then we, Your people, the sheep of Your pasture, will pause and give You thanks forever; Your praise will be told by our generation to the next.

1.verse: Psalm 80 - For the worship leader. A song of Asaph to the tune “The Lilies.” Psalm 80 is a communal lament composed in Judah (the Southern Kingdom) after the fall of Israel (the Northern Kingdom) in 722 B.C. Turn Your ear toward us, Shepherd of Israel, You who lead the children of Joseph like a flock. You who sit enthroned above heaven’s winged creatures, radiate Your light!

2.verse: In the presence of Ephraim, Benjamin, and Manasseh, arouse Your strength and power, and save us!

3.verse: Bring us back to You, God. Turn the light of Your face upon us so that we will be rescued from this sea of darkness.

4.verse: O Eternal God, Commander of heaven’s armies, how long will You remain angry at the prayers of Your sons and daughters?

5.verse: You have given them tears for food; You have given them an abundance of tears to drink.

6.verse: You have made us a source of trouble for our neighbors— our enemies laugh to each other behind our backs.

7.verse: O God, Commander of heaven’s armies, bring us back to You. Turn the light of Your face upon us so that we will be rescued from this sea of darkness.

8.verse: You took us like a grapevine dug from the soil of Egypt; You forced out the nations and transplanted it in Your land.

9.verse: You groomed the ground around it, planted it so it would root deep into the earth, and it covered all the land.

10.verse: As it grew, the mountains were blanketed by its shadow; the mighty cedars were covered by its branches.

11.verse: The plant extended its branches to the Mediterranean Sea, and spread its shoots all the way to the Euphrates River.

12.verse: God, why have You pulled down the wall that protected it so that everyone who wanders by can pick its sweet grapes?

13.verse: The wild boar of the forest eats it all, and the creatures of the field feast upon it.

14.verse: O God, Commander of heaven’s armies, come back to us. Gaze down from heaven and see what has happened. Keep watch over this vine, and nourish it.

15.verse: Look after the saplings which You planted with Your own right hand, the child whom You have raised and nurtured for Yourself.

16.verse: Your enemies have chopped it down and burned it with fire; may they be destroyed by the sight of Your rebuke.

17.verse: Let Your protective hand rest on the one who is at Your right hand, the child of man whom You have raised and nurtured for Yourself.

18.verse: Then we will not turn away from You. Bring us back to life! And we will call out for You!

19.verse: O Eternal God, Commander of heaven’s armies, bring us back to You. Turn the light of Your face upon us so that we will be rescued from this sea of darkness.

1.verse: Psalm 81 - For the worship leader. A song of Asaph accompanied by the harp. God’s covenant people celebrated many festivals honoring God and His provisions. Poets composed songs specifically for use on feast days. Psalm 81 is one of those. It was written to celebrate the Festival of Booths. God commanded His people to celebrate this festival every year so they would remember how God provided for them as they moved toward the promised land (Deuteronomy 16:13–15). A portion of this psalm (verses 5b–16) would have been sung by the lead musician as if he were speaking for God. In the annual rhythm of festivals and praise, God is reminding the people of all He has done for them and of their past disobedience in spite of His love. He is also calling His people to renew their commitment to Him, a reasonable request on a holiday honoring Him. Sing with joy to God, our strength, our fortress. Raise your voices to the True God of Jacob.

2.verse: Sing and strike up a melody; sound the tambourine, strum the sweet lyre and the harp.

3.verse: Blow the trumpet to announce the new moon, the full moon, the day of our feast.

4.verse: For this is prescribed for Israel, a rule ordained by the True God of Jacob.

5.verse: A precept established by God in Joseph during His journey in Egypt. I hear it said in a language foreign to me:

6.verse: “I removed the burden from your shoulders; I removed heavy baskets from your hands.

7.verse: You cried out to Me, I heard your distress, and I delivered you; I answered you from the secret place, where clouds of thunder roll. I tested you at the waters of Meribah. [pause]

8.verse: “O My people, hear Me; I will rebuke you. Israel, Israel! If you would only listen to Me.

9.verse: Do not surround yourselves with other gods or bow down to strange gods.

10.verse: I am the Eternal, your True God. I liberated you from slavery, led you out from the land of Egypt. If you open your mouth wide, I will fill it.

11.verse: “But My own people did not hear My voice! Israel refused to obey Me.

12.verse: So I freed them to follow their hard hearts, to do what they thought was best.

13.verse: If only My people would hear My voice and Israel would follow My direction!

14.verse: Then I would not hesitate to humble their enemies and defeat their opposition Myself.

15.verse: Those who hate the Eternal will cower in His presence, pretending to submit; they secretly loathe Him, yet their doom is forever.

16.verse: But you—I will feed you the best wheat and satisfy you with honey out of the rock.”

1.verse: Psalm 82 - A song of Asaph. Psalm 82 provides an image of a heavenly scene in which God accuses His heavenly messengers of not caring for the poor and pursuing justice. The True God stands to preside over the heavenly council. He pronounces judgment on the so-called gods.

2.verse: He asks: “How long will you judge dishonestly and be partial to the wicked?” [pause]

3.verse: “Stand up for the poor and the orphan; advocate for the rights of the afflicted and those in need.

4.verse: Deliver the poor and the needy; rescue them from their evil oppressors.”

5.verse: These bullies are ignorant; they have no understanding of My ways. So as they walk in darkness, the foundations of the earth tremble.

6.verse: I said, “Though you are gods and children of the Most High,

7.verse: You will die no differently than any mortal; you will fall like one of the princes.”

8.verse: Rise up, O True God; judge the rulers of the earth, for all the nations are Yours.

1.verse: Psalm 83 - A song of Asaph. O True God, do not be quiet any longer. Do not stay silent or be still, O God.

2.verse: Look now, Your enemies are causing a commotion; those who hate You are rising up!

3.verse: They are conniving against Your people, conspiring against those You cherish.

4.verse: They say, “Join us. Let’s wipe the entire nation off the face of the earth so no one will remember Israel’s name.”

5.verse: They are all in it together, thinking as one, and making a pact against You:

6.verse: The people of Edom and Ishmael; the Moabites and the Hagrites;

7.verse: Gebal, Ammon, and Amalek; Philistia with the residents of Tyre.

8.verse: And the powerful Assyrians have joined the alliance to add their strength and support the descendants of Lot: Moab and Ammon. [pause]

9.verse: Do to these nations what You did to Midian, to Sisera and Jabin at the raging waters of Kishon.

10.verse: They were destroyed at En-dor; they became like dung, fertilizer for the ground.

11.verse: Make their rulers like Oreb and Zeeb, all their princes like Zebah and Zalmunna,

12.verse: Who schemed, “We should own the meadows of the True God, let’s take them!”

13.verse: O my God, blow them away like a tumbleweed, scatter them like dust in a whirlwind.

14.verse: As a wildfire charges through the forest or a flame sprints up the mountainside,

15.verse: Send Your raging winds to chase them, hunt them down, and terrify them with Your storm.

16.verse: Redden their faces in shame so that they will turn and seek Your holy name, Eternal One.

17.verse: May they face disappointment and anxiety forever; may they be ashamed and die.

18.verse: May they know that You and You alone, whose name is the Eternal, are the Most High, the Supreme Ruler over all the earth.

1.verse: Psalm 84 - For the worship leader. A song of the sons of Korah accompanied by the harp. How lovely is Your temple, Your dwelling place on earth, O Eternal One, Commander of heaven’s armies.

2.verse: How I long to be there—my soul is spent, wanting, waiting to walk in the courts of the Eternal. My whole being sings joyfully to the living God.

3.verse: Just as the sparrow seeks her home, and the swallow finds in her own nest a place to lay her young, I, too, seek Your altars, my King and my God, Commander of heaven’s armies.

4.verse: How blessed are those who make Your house their home, who live with You; they are constantly praising You. [pause]

5.verse: Blessed are those who make You their strength, for they treasure every step of the journey [to Zion].

6.verse: On their way through the valley of Baca, they stop and dig wells to collect the refreshing spring water, and the early rains fill the pools.

7.verse: They journey from place to place, gaining strength along the way; until they meet God in Zion.

8.verse: O Eternal God, Commander of heaven’s armies, listen to my prayer. O please listen, God of Jacob. [pause]

9.verse: O True God, look at our shield, our protector, see the face of Your anointed king, and defend our defender.

10.verse: Just one day in the courts of Your temple is greater than a thousand anywhere else. I would rather serve as a porter at my God’s doorstep than live in luxury in the house of the wicked.

11.verse: For the Eternal God is a sun and a shield. The Eternal grants favor and glory; He doesn’t deny any good thing to those who live with integrity.

12.verse: O Eternal One, Commander of heaven’s armies, how fortunate are those who trust You.

1.verse: Psalm 85 - For the worship leader. A song of the sons of Korah. O Eternal One, there was a time when You were gracious to Your land; You returned Jacob’s descendants from their captivity.

2.verse: You forgave the iniquity of Your people, covered all of their sins. [pause]

3.verse: There was a time when You restrained all of Your fierce wrath, when You cooled Your hot anger.

4.verse: O God of our salvation, bring us back again—as You did before— and put away Your anger toward us.

5.verse: Will You be mad at us forever? Will You continue to be angry with our children and theirs?

6.verse: Will You not bring us back to life once more so that we, Your people, will find joy and pleasure in You?

7.verse: O Eternal One, show us Your unfailing love; give us what we truly need: Your salvation.

8.verse: I will hear what the True God—the Eternal—will say, for He will speak peace over His people, peace over those who faithfully follow Him, [but do not let them abuse His gift and return to foolish ways].

9.verse: Without a doubt, His salvation is near for those who revere Him so that He will be with us again and all His glory will fill this land.

10.verse: Unfailing love and truth have met on their way; righteousness and peace have kissed one another.

11.verse: Truth will spring from the earth like a plant, and justice will look down from the sky.

12.verse: Yes, the Eternal will plant goodness in the earth, and our land will yield great abundance.

13.verse: Justice will come before Him, marking out a path, setting a way for His feet.

1.verse: Psalm 86 - A prayer of David. O Eternal One, lend an ear to my prayer and answer me, for I am weak and wanting.

2.verse: Safeguard my soul, for I remain loyal to You. Save me, Your servant, who trusts in You, my God.

3.verse: O Lord, please be merciful to me, as all day long I cry out to You.

4.verse: Bring joy into the life of Your servant, for it’s only to You, O Lord, that I offer my soul.

5.verse: O Lord, You are good and ready to forgive; Your loyal love flows generously over all who cry out to You.

6.verse: O Eternal One, lend an ear and hear my prayer; listen to my pleading voice.

7.verse: When times of trouble come, I will call to You because I know You will respond to me.

8.verse: O Lord, You stand alone among the other gods; nothing they have done compares to Your wonderful works.

9.verse: O Lord, all the peoples of earth—every nation You established— will come to You, bowing low to worship, and rightly honor Your great name.

10.verse: For You are great, and Your works are wondrous; You are the one True God.

11.verse: O Eternal One, guide me along Your path so that I will live in Your truth. Unite my divided heart so that I will fear Your great name.

12.verse: O Lord, my God! I praise You with all that I am. I will rightly honor Your great name forever.

13.verse: For Your loyal love for me is so great it is beyond comparison. You have rescued my soul from the depths of the grave.

14.verse: O True God, arrogant people are after me. A violent gang wants to kill me; they have no interest in You or Your ways.

15.verse: But Lord, You are a God full of compassion, generous in grace, slow to anger, and boundless in loyal love and truth.

16.verse: Look at me, and grant me Your favor. Invest Your strength in me, Your servant, and rescue me, Your handmaiden’s child.

17.verse: Give me a sign so I may know Your goodness rests on me and so those who hate me will be red with shame at the sight of it. For You, O Eternal One, have come to my aid and offered me relief.

1.verse: Psalm 87 - A song of the sons of Korah. He laid His foundation on the sacred mountains.

2.verse: The Eternal loves Zion’s gates; He prefers it over any other place where Jacob’s descendants make their homes.

3.verse: Spectacular things are said about you, O Jerusalem, city of the True God. [pause]

4.verse: God says, “I tell of some who know Me in Egypt and Babylon; behold, My people are in Philistia, Tyre, and Ethiopia too: ‘This person was born there.’”

5.verse: It is said of Zion, “This person and that person were born in her.” The Most High God has established that city and makes her strong.

6.verse: When keeping track of His people, the Eternal surely notices, “This one was born in Zion.” [pause]

7.verse: Those who sing and those who dance will say together, “All my fountains of joy are in You.”

1.verse: Psalm 88 - For the worship leader. A song of the sons of Korah accompanied by dance. A contemplative song of Heman the Ezrahite. This individual lament was composed by someone afflicted with a grave illness, feeling lonely and abandoned by God. This song is reminiscent of Job’s sufferings. O Eternal One! O True God my Savior! I cry out to You all the time, under the sun and the moon.

2.verse: Let my voice reach You! Please listen to my prayers!

3.verse: My soul is deeply troubled, and my heart can’t bear the weight of this sorrow. I feel so close to death.

4.verse: I’m like the poor and helpless who die alone, left for dead, as good as the unknowable sea of souls lying under our feet,

5.verse: Forsaken by Him and cut off from His hand, abandoned among the dead who rest in their graves. And You have sent me to be forgotten with them, in the lowest pits of the earth, in the darkest canyons of the ocean.

6.verse: Forsaken by Him and cut off from His hand, abandoned among the dead who rest in their graves. And You have sent me to be forgotten with them, in the lowest pits of the earth, in the darkest canyons of the ocean.

7.verse: You crush me with Your anger. You crash against me like the relentless, angry sea. [pause]

8.verse: Those whom I have known, who have been with me, You have gathered like sheaves and cast to the four winds. They can’t bear to look me in the eye, and they are horrified when they think of me. I am in a trap and cannot be free.

9.verse: My eyes grow dim, weakened by this sickness; it is taking my strength from me. Like a worn cloth, my hands are unfolded before You daily, O Eternal One.

10.verse: Are You the miracle-worker for the dead? Will they rise from the dark shadows to worship You again? [pause]

11.verse: Will Your great love be proclaimed in the grave or Your faithfulness be remembered in whispers like mists throughout the place of ruin?

12.verse: Are Your wonders known in the dominion of darkness, or is Your righteousness recognized in a land where all is forgotten?

13.verse: But I am calling out to You, Eternal One. My prayers rise before You with every new sun!

14.verse: Why do You turn Your head and brush me aside, O Eternal One? Why are You avoiding me?

15.verse: Since the days of my youth, I have been sick and close to death. My helpless soul has suffered Your silent horrors; now I am desperate.

16.verse: Your rage spills over me like rivers of fire; Your assaults have all but destroyed me.

17.verse: They surround me like a flood, rising throughout the day, closing in from every direction.

18.verse: You have taken from me the one I love and my friend; even the light of my acquaintances are darkness.

1.verse: Psalm 89 - A contemplative song of Ethan the Ezrahite. Psalm 89 begins on a note of praise and ends with a lament. The heart of this psalm recalls God’s choice of David as king and God’s covenant with him to establish an eternal dynasty (2 Samuel 7). I will sing of Your unfailing love, Eternal One, forever. I will speak of Your faithfulness to all generations.

2.verse: I will tell how Your unfailing love will always stand strong; and how Your faithfulness is established in the heavens above.

3.verse: You said, “I have made a covenant with My chosen one. I made My servant, David, this promise:

4.verse: ‘I will establish your dynasty so that you and your descendants will always be secure. Your rule will continue for generations to come.’” [pause]

5.verse: Let the heavens join in praising the wonderful works of the Eternal. The holy ones have gathered, singing of Your faithfulness.

6.verse: For there is no one above who compares to the Eternal, not one of heaven’s creatures is like Him in the least.

7.verse: In the council of holy ones, God is lifted high and feared; His presence overwhelms all who are near Him.

8.verse: O Eternal God, Commander of heaven’s armies, who is mighty like You? You are completely faithful; that’s why we trust You.

9.verse: The ocean waters are at Your command. When violent waves rise up, You still them.

10.verse: You defeated Rahab, that ancient monster of chaos, and left it lifeless. You routed Your enemies and scattered them by Your great arm of power.

11.verse: Everything in the sky above and the earth below are Yours. The world and all it contains are Yours, for You created them all.

12.verse: Everything was created by You—the north, the south— the mountains of Tabor and Hermon echo joyously the song of Your name.

13.verse: Your arm is strong. Your grip is powerful. Your right hand is raised up high.

14.verse: Your rule is rooted deeply in justice and righteousness— unfailing love and truth lead from the way ahead of You.

15.verse: How happy are those who have learned how to praise You; those who journey through life by the light of Your face.

16.verse: Every hour of the day, they rejoice at the sound of Your name. They are lifted up and encouraged by Your righteousness.

17.verse: For You are the beauty of their strength. On account of Your favor, our strength, our horn, is increased.

18.verse: For our shield of protection comes from the Eternal, and the Holy One of Israel has given us our king.

19.verse: Long ago You spoke through a vision to Your faithful followers, saying, “I have given help to a warrior; I have chosen a hero from among My people.

20.verse: I have found David, My servant. With My holy oil, I have anointed him king.

21.verse: My strong hand will stay with him and sustain him, regardless of trial or foe. My mighty arm will be his strength and shield.

22.verse: The deceit of his enemies will not outwit him. The wicked will not defeat him.

23.verse: I will pound his enemies right in front of him. I will strike down all those who hate him.

24.verse: My faithfulness and unfailing love will never leave him; through My name, strength and power will be his.

25.verse: I will extend his rule over the oceans, his right hand will control the rivers.

26.verse: He will cry out to Me, ‘You are my Father, my God, and the Rock of my salvation!’

27.verse: I will make him My firstborn; no earthly king shall be greater.

28.verse: My unfailing love will always be with him, protecting him; My covenant with him will never be broken.

29.verse: I will ensure his family’s future forever; his dynasty will last as long as the heavens.

30.verse: If his children turn away from Me and forsake My law, if they refuse to walk according to My judgments,

31.verse: If they disobey My instructions and ignore My commandments,

32.verse: Then I will use the rod to punish their sins and stripes to deal with their iniquity.

33.verse: And yet My unfailing love of him will remain steadfast and strong. I will not be unfaithful to My promise.

34.verse: I will not violate My covenant, nor will I alter even one word of what My lips have spoken.

35.verse: These words I have pledged in My holiness once and for all, and I will not lie to David.

36.verse: As long as the sun lights the day before Me, his descendants will continue to rule. His kingdom will last forever.

37.verse: His dynasty will stand firm for all time like the moon, the faithful witness that stands watch in the night sky.” [pause]

38.verse: But what now? You have turned Your back and walked away! Your full fury burns against Your anointed king.

39.verse: You made a covenant with Your servant, then renounced it, casting his sacred crown into the dust.

40.verse: You have broken down the walls that protected Your servant; his defenses are reduced to a pile of rubble.

41.verse: Strangers now plunder all that he has left; he has become a laughingstock among his neighbors.

42.verse: You have made his adversaries strong. His enemies celebrate their victory.

43.verse: You have dulled the blade of his sword, and You have not helped him stand strong in the battle.

44.verse: You have brought his days of splendor to an abrupt end; You have toppled his throne; it sits in the dust.

45.verse: You have cut short the days of his youth and have covered him with shame and despair. [pause]

46.verse: How long must we endure, O Eternal One? Will You hide Yourself forever? How long will Your wrath burn like fire?

47.verse: Remember my days are numbered. Have You created the children of Adam to live futile lives?

48.verse: Death waits at the gate; who can escape and live? Does the grave hold exceptions for any of us? Who can deliver us from the power of the grave? [pause]

49.verse: O Lord, where is the unfailing love You showed in times past? And where is the proof of Your faithfulness to David?

50.verse: Remember how Your servants are ridiculed, O Lord; how I carry within me the insults of so many peoples.

51.verse: Your enemies are mocking me, O Eternal One, mocking every step Your anointed one made.

52.verse: Praise the Eternal always. Amen. Amen.

1.verse: Book Four - There are endless reasons to praise God, and many of them are included in the Book of Psalms. Book Four (Psalms 90–106) is made up of songs that praise and celebrate God for His creation, strength, work in history, and kingship. Although these songs are written to honor God, many require something from us. Throughout these psalms is the Hebrew word hallelujah, translated “Praise the Eternal!” That’s not just a passive verb, as in, “Praise be to the Eternal”; it’s an active imperative! We are commanded to praise Him. We are commanded to join angels above, people below, and all creatures in praising Him! Psalm 90 - A prayer of Moses, a man of God. Lord, You have always been our refuge. Our ancestors made You their home long ago.

2.verse: Before mountains were born, before You fashioned the earth and filled it with life, from ages past to distant futures, You are truly God.

3.verse: You turn people back to dust, saying, “Go back to the dust, children of Adam.”

4.verse: For You a thousand years is like a day when it is over, a watch during the night; there is no difference to You.

5.verse: You release the waters of death to sweep mankind away in his slumber. In the morning, we are blades of grass, Growing rapidly under the sun but withering quickly; yet in the evening, we fade and die, soon to be cut down.

6.verse: You release the waters of death to sweep mankind away in his slumber. In the morning, we are blades of grass, Growing rapidly under the sun but withering quickly; yet in the evening, we fade and die, soon to be cut down.

7.verse: For Your anger has consumed us. Your wrath has shaken us to the core and left us deeply troubled.

8.verse: You have written our offenses before You— the light of Your presence shines brightly on our secret sins, and we can’t run or hide.

9.verse: For all our days are spent beneath Your wrath; our youth gives way to old age, and then one day our years come to an end with a sigh.

10.verse: We may journey through life for 70 years; some may live and breathe 80 years—if we are strong. Yet our time here is only toil and trouble; soon our days are gone, and we fly away.

11.verse: Who can truly comprehend the power unleashed by Your anger? Your wrath matches the fear that is due to You.

12.verse: Teach us to number our days so that we may truly live and achieve wisdom.

13.verse: How long will we wait here alone? Return, O Eternal One, with mercy. Rescue Your servants with compassion.

14.verse: With every sun’s rising, surprise us with Your love, satisfy us with Your kindness. Then we will sing with joy and celebrate every day we are alive.

15.verse: You have spent many days afflicting us with pain and sorrow; now match those with years of unspent joy.

16.verse: Let Your work of love be on display for all Your servants; let Your children see Your majesty.

17.verse: And then let the beauty and grace of the Lord—our God—rest upon us and bring success to all we do; yes, bring success to all we do!

1.verse: Psalm 91 - He who takes refuge in the shelter of the Most High will be safe in the shadow of the Almighty.

2.verse: He will say to the Eternal, “My shelter, my mighty fortress, my God, I place all my trust in You.”

3.verse: For He will rescue you from the snares set by your enemies who entrap you and from deadly plagues.

4.verse: Like a bird protecting its young, God will cover you with His feathers, will protect you under His great wings; His faithfulness will form a shield around you, a rock-solid wall to protect you.

5.verse: Psalm 91 is a beautiful psalm of trust in God. But how does God take care of all His people, all at the same time? Well, keep reading because Psalm 91 is one of just a few places in Scripture that describe what we might call “guardian angels” (Exodus 23:20; Psalm 43:3). Though rare, these passages teach that God is not alone in maintaining and protecting His creation and His people. He has made a host of heavenly messengers ready to do His bidding, and His bidding is often to guard His people throughout their lives and protect them—sometimes from dangers they are not even aware of. You will not dread the terrors that haunt the night or enemy arrows that fly in the day

6.verse: Or the plagues that lurk in darkness or the disasters that wreak havoc at noon.

7.verse: A thousand may fall on your left, ten thousand may die on your right, but these horrors won’t come near you.

8.verse: Only your eyes will witness the punishment that awaits the evil, but you will not suffer because of it.

9.verse: For you made the Eternal [your] refuge, the Most High your only home.

10.verse: No evil will come to you; plagues will be turned away at your door.

11.verse: He will command His heavenly messengers to guard you, to keep you safe in every way.

12.verse: They will hold you up in their hands so that you will not crash, or fall, or even graze your foot on a stone.

13.verse: You will walk on the lion and the cobra; you will trample the lion and the serpent underfoot.

14.verse: “Because he clings to Me in love, I will rescue him from harm; I will set him above danger. Because he has known Me by name,

15.verse: He will call on Me, and I will answer. I’ll be with him through hard times; I’ll rescue him and grant him honor.

16.verse: I’ll reward him with many good years on this earth and let him witness My salvation.”

1.verse: Psalm 92 - A song for the Sabbath Day. Psalm 92 gives thanks to God for His salvation. The superscription provides the only reference to the Sabbath in the Book of Psalms. How good it is to give thanks to the Eternal and to praise Your name with song, O Most High;

2.verse: To speak of Your unfailing love in the morning and rehearse Your faithfulness as night begins to fall.

3.verse: How good it is to praise to the sound of strings—lute and harp— the stirring melodies of the lyre.

4.verse: Because You, O Eternal One, thrill me with the things You have done, I will sing with joy in light of Your deeds.

5.verse: Your works are marvelous, O Eternal One! Your thoughts are unfathomable.

6.verse: But a weak-minded man can’t understand this; foolish people are unable to see

7.verse: That evil men sprout like grass and wicked men flourish, only so that they will be doomed forever.

8.verse: But You, O Eternal One, are above all, forever.

9.verse: As for Your enemies, O Eternal One, their fate is obvious: those who hate You will not survive; those who practice evil will be broken in pieces.

10.verse: But You have made me strong as a wild ox, anointed me with the refreshing oil of Your blessing.

11.verse: And I have seen with my own eyes my enemies defeated; I have heard with my own ears my attackers cut down.

12.verse: Those who are devoted to God will flourish like budding date-palm trees; they will grow strong and tall like cedars in Lebanon.

13.verse: Those planted in the house of the Eternal will thrive in the courts of our God.

14.verse: They will bear fruit into old age; even in winter, they will be green and full of sap

15.verse: To display that the Eternal is righteous. He is my rock, and there is no shadow of evil in Him.

1.verse: Psalm 93 - The Eternal reigns, clothed in majesty; He is dressed in power; He has surrounded Himself with strength. He has established the world, and it will never be toppled.

2.verse: Your throne was established from the beginning of the world, O God, and You are everlasting.

3.verse: The waters have risen, O Eternal One; the sound of pounding waves is deafening. The waters have roared with power.

4.verse: More powerful than the thunder of mighty rivers, more powerful than the mighty waves in the ocean is the Eternal on high!

5.verse: Your teachings are true; Your decrees sure. Sacredness adorns Your house, O Eternal One, forevermore.

1.verse: Psalm 94 - O Eternal God of vengeance, O God who sets things right, shine upon us.

2.verse: Rise, O Judge who presides over the earth, and pronounce Your sentence upon the proud. Give them what they deserve!

3.verse: How long, O Eternal One, how long will the guilty revel in their prosperity?

4.verse: Arrogance pours from their mouths; all these troublemakers brag of their exploits.

5.verse: They have broken Your people to pieces, O Eternal One, and brought ruin to Your future generations.

6.verse: They slay a widow, kill a newcomer, and murder an orphan.

7.verse: Then they say, “The Eternal can’t see what we’re up to; the God of Jacob’s people pays no attention to us.”

8.verse: Think, brainless people; stupid people, when will you get it?

9.verse: Does the God who set the ear in its place not hear? Does the God who made the eye not see?

10.verse: Does the God who teaches the nations and guides humanity to knowledge, not exercise just correction?

11.verse: The Eternal knows the highest thoughts of the wise, and they are worthless.

12.verse: How fortunate are those You discipline, O Eternal One, those You train by Your divine law;

13.verse: You relieve them in times of distress, until a grave is dug for evildoers.

14.verse: The Eternal will not abandon His people; He will not turn away from those He redeemed

15.verse: Because justice is coming for those who do what is right and all the good-hearted will pursue it.

16.verse: Who will back me up when evildoers come against me? Who is willing to take my side against the wicked?

17.verse: If the Eternal had not come to my rescue, my soul would have descended to the land where death silences every voice.

18.verse: When I said, “My foot is slipping!” Your unfailing love, O Eternal One, held me up.

19.verse: When anxiety overtakes me and worries are many, Your comfort lightens my soul.

20.verse: Can wicked tyrants be Your allies? Will You align with rulers who create havoc with unjust decrees?

21.verse: They have joined forces against the life of the just-living, the right-seeking, and have sentenced the innocent to death.

22.verse: But the Eternal has been my citadel; my God, a sure safe haven.

23.verse: He will fold their wickedness back upon them, and because they are malicious, He will silence them. The Eternal, our True God, will scatter them.

1.verse: Psalm 95 - Come, let us worship in song, a joyful offering to the Eternal. Shout! Shout with joy to the rock of our liberation.

2.verse: Come face-to-face with God, and give thanks; with loud and joyful voices, praise Him in songs.

3.verse: For the Eternal is a great God, and a great King, supreme over all gods.

4.verse: Within His control are the very depths of the earth; the mountaintops too—they all belong to Him.

5.verse: The sea belongs to Him, for He created it—scooped and filled it— with His hands He made the dry land—every valley and mountain.

6.verse: Come, let us worship Him. Everyone bow down; kneel before the Eternal who made us.

7.verse: For He is our God and we are His people, the flock of His pasture, His sheep protected and nurtured by His hand. Today, if He speaks, hear His voice.

8.verse: “Don’t harden your hearts the way they did in the bitter uprising at Meribah or like that day they complained in the wilderness of Massah.

9.verse: Your ancestors tested Me, wanted Me to prove Myself though they had seen that nothing was too great for Me.

10.verse: For 40 years I despised that grumbling generation and said, ‘Their hearts are unfaithful; they no longer walk in My ways; though I call, they do not listen to My voice.’

11.verse: That is why in My anger I swore, ‘They will never enter into My rest.’”

1.verse: Psalm 96 - Sing a new song to the Eternal; sing in one voice to the Eternal, all the earth.

2.verse: Sing to the Eternal of all the good things He’s done. Bless His name; broadcast the good news of His salvation each and every day.

3.verse: Enlighten the nations to His splendor; describe His wondrous acts to all people.

4.verse: For the Eternal is great indeed and praiseworthy; feared and reverenced above all gods, the True God shall be.

5.verse: For all human-made, lifeless gods are worthless idols, but the Eternal plotted the vast heavens, shaped every last detail.

6.verse: Honor and majesty precede Him; strength and beauty infuse His holy sanctuary.

7.verse: One of the great themes of Scripture and Psalms is the kingship of God. While lesser kings come and go, God is the One who ultimately rules and reigns over His people, and by extension over the rest of creation. Psalm 96 and others in the collection are often referred to as “enthronement” psalms because they declare boldly and unequivocally that the Eternal is King. There is evidence to suggest that an annual festival at the beginning of the year provided an opportunity to reaffirm the people’s loyalty to the one True God. Psalm 96 calls for new songs to be composed and sung to God and about God as a witness. The enthronement psalms call the world and all its inhabitants to come and recognize His beauty and majesty. Give all credit to the Eternal, families of the world! Credit Him with glory, honor, and strength!

8.verse: Credit Him with the glory worthy of His magnificent name; gather your sacrifice, and present it at His temple.

9.verse: Bow down to the Eternal, adorned in holiness; lay awestruck before Him, trembling, all people of the earth.

10.verse: Shout out to the nations, “The Eternal reigns! Yes, indeed, the world is anchored and will not shake loose. He governs all people with a fair hand.”

11.verse: And so, let the heavens resound in gladness! Let joy be the earth’s rhythm as the sea and all its creatures roar.

12.verse: Let the fields grow in triumph, a grand jubilee for all that live there. Let all the trees of the forest dig in and reach high with songs of joy before the Eternal,

13.verse: For the Eternal is on His way: yes, He is coming to judge the earth. He will set the world right by His standards, and by His faithfulness, He will examine the people.

1.verse: Psalm 97 - The Eternal reigns powerful over all; let the earth sing with joy; let the distant islands celebrate.

2.verse: Clouds and deep darkness encircle Him; righteousness and justice are the bedrock of His rule.

3.verse: Fire precedes Him; it burns away His opponents on all sides.

4.verse: With His lightning flashing about, He illuminates the world; the earth watches and trembles.

5.verse: Like wax before the flame, mountains melt when the Eternal appears, the Master of the whole earth.

6.verse: The heavens display His order and perfect justice; all peoples witness His magnificence.

7.verse: Those who worship idols, who boast in the impotent creations of human hands, will be shamed. Worship Him, all you gods.

8.verse: Zion heard and was glad, and the daughters of Judah celebrated because they saw Your justice, O Eternal One.

9.verse: For You are the Eternal, the Most High, over the entire world; You far exceed all gods.

10.verse: Hate evil, you lovers of the Eternal. He protects the souls of those who follow Him; He rescues them from the devices of the wicked.

11.verse: Light is sown in the just; as it grows, it brings joy to the pure of heart.

12.verse: Celebrate the Eternal God, all you who are faithful; offer thanks to His holy name.

1.verse: Psalm 98 - A song. Compose a new song, and sing it to the Eternal because of the unbelievable things He has done; He has won the victory with the skill of His right hand and strength of His holy arm.

2.verse: The Eternal has made it clear that He saves, and He has shown the nations that He does what is right.

3.verse: He has been true to His promises; fresh in His mind is His unfailing love for all of Israel. Even the ends of the earth have witnessed how our God saves.

4.verse: This hymn invites all the people on earth and creation itself to join in singing a new song of “beautiful noise” celebrating God’s justice and victories. Raise your voices; make a beautiful noise to the Eternal, all the earth. Let your joy explode into song and praise;

5.verse: Make music to the Eternal with the harp; sing a beautiful melody with the harp and chorus.

6.verse: With trumpets and horns, fill the air with joyful sounds to the King, the Eternal.

7.verse: Let the sea rumble and roar, and all the creatures it holds shout praise; let the whole world and all those who live in it join the celebration.

8.verse: Let the rivers applaud and the mountains join in joyful song

9.verse: In the presence of the Eternal because He is coming to judge the earth. He is coming, and His judgment will be what is right for the world and just to all people.

1.verse: Psalm 99 - The Eternal is the king ruling over all; let all people shake in fear. He sits on His throne, settled between winged guardians; let the planet tremble.

2.verse: The Eternal is great in the hearts of His people; He has made Zion His sacred mountain, and He reigns majestic over all people.

3.verse: Let them express praise and gratitude to Your amazing and awesome name— because He is holy, perfect and exalted in His power.

4.verse: The King who rules with strength also treasures justice. You created order and established what is right. You have carried out justice and done what is right to the people of Jacob.

5.verse: Lift up the Eternal our God in your heart; bow down to the earth where He rests His feet. He is holy, perfect and exalted in His power.

6.verse: Moses and Aaron were two of His priests; Samuel was among those who called out to Him. They asked the Eternal for help, and He answered them.

7.verse: He answered them from a column of cloud; they heeded His testimonies and lived by the laws He gave them.

8.verse: You answered them, Eternal our God; You were, to them, a God who forgives, yet You did not ignore what they did wrong and punished them fairly as well.

9.verse: Lift up the Eternal our God in your hearts, and celebrate His goodness at His holy mountain, for the Eternal our God is holy, perfect and exalted in His power.

1.verse: Psalm 100 - A song of thanks. Psalm 100 is one of the best known and most loved psalms. This hymn of thanksgiving invites the whole world to come to God’s temple in Jerusalem and enter its sacred spaces with unbridled joy and hearts filled with gratitude. And why should we? The psalm provides the answer. Not only has God created us—a gracious act of love in and of itself—but He has made us His own people. He has chosen us and loved us. As with Psalm 23, God’s people are cast in the role as sheep living well in His pasture. The psalm ends on a high note of confidence and hope. At all times—but perhaps more in times of difficulty—we need to be reminded of what is true. Regardless of what seems to be happening around us, the Eternal is good; His love and faithfulness will endure forever. Raise your voices; make a beautiful noise to the Eternal, all the earth.

2.verse: Serve the Eternal gladly; enter into His presence singing songs of joy!

3.verse: Know this: the Eternal One Himself is the True God. He is the One who made us; we have not made ourselves; we are His people, like sheep grazing in His fields.

4.verse: Go through His gates, giving thanks; walk through His courts, giving praise. Offer Him your gratitude and praise His holy name.

5.verse: Because the Eternal is good, His loyal love and mercy will never end, and His truth will last throughout all generations.

1.verse: Psalm 101 - A song of David. I will sing of God’s unsparing love and justice; to You, O Eternal One, I will sing praises.

2.verse: I will seek to live a life of integrity; when will You come to me? I will walk in my house with an honest and true heart.

3.verse: I will refuse to look on any sordid thing; I detest the worthless deeds of those who stray; evil will not get a hold on me.

4.verse: I will rid my heart of all perversion; I will not flirt with any evil.

5.verse: Whoever secretly slanders his neighbor, I will silence; I will not tolerate a condescending smirk, an arrogant heart.

6.verse: I will look for those who are loyal in the land so that they may live with me and know my pleasure. Whoever walks with integrity will enter my service.

7.verse: The one who makes a habit of deceit will not be welcome in my house; The one who lies will not remain in my presence for long.

8.verse: Every morning I will purge all the wicked from the land So as to rid the city of the Eternal of those who practice evil.

1.verse: Psalm 102 - A prayer of the weak and oppressed, when he turns his complaints to the Eternal. Hear me, O Eternal One, hear my prayer! Hear my lonely desperate cry for help.

2.verse: Do not hide from me when my days are filled with anguish; Lend Your ear to my wailing, and answer me quickly when I call.

3.verse: For my days come and go, vanishing like smoke, and my bones are charred like bricks of a hearth.

4.verse: My heart is beaten down like grass withered and scorched in the summer heat; I can’t even remember to eat.

5.verse: My body is shaken by my groans; my bones cling to my skin, holding on for dear life.

6.verse: I am like a solitary owl in the wilderness; I am a lost and lonely screech owl at home in the rubble.

7.verse: I stare at the ceiling, awake in my bed; I am alone, a defenseless sparrow perched on a roof.

8.verse: All day long my enemies chide me; those who mock me spit out my name as a curse.

9.verse: For ashes have become my bread; my tears fall into my drink

10.verse: Because of the depth of Your wrath. You have brought me up and then hurled me aside.

11.verse: My days go by like a long shadow—stretched thin and disappearing— I shrivel up like grass baked in the hot sun.

12.verse: But You, O Eternal One, remain forever, and Your name endures to all generations.

13.verse: You will rise up once again and remember Your love for Zion; it is time to have mercy on Your city; yes, it is the divinely appointed time.

14.verse: Your faithful servants take pleasure in her every stone; they even delight in the dust of her streets.

15.verse: Days are coming when nations will tremble at the name of the Eternal; all the rulers of the earth will bow down to Your glory.

16.verse: For He will return to rebuild His city, Zion; He will be seen in His splendor.

17.verse: He will listen to the prayer of the impoverished and welcome their prayers.

18.verse: Let this record be kept for posterity so that people not yet born may praise the Eternal.

19.verse: Tell them that He looked down from holy heights, His heavenly sanctuary; the Eternal looked down from heaven and closely watched the earth,

20.verse: Hearing the prisoners’ groans— releasing those awaiting execution—

21.verse: That the name of the Eternal would resound in Zion, and His praise would be proclaimed in Jerusalem

22.verse: When the peoples gather and the nations’ leaders assemble to worship the Eternal.

23.verse: Along my way He has sapped my strength; He has shortened my days here on earth.

24.verse: I said, “O my True God, don’t take me away in the middle of my life; Unlike me, Your years continually unfold throughout all generations.”

25.verse: In the beginning, You laid the foundation of the earth and set the skies above us with Your own hands.

26.verse: But while they will someday pass away, You remain forever; when they wear out like old clothes, You will roll them up and change them into something new, and they will pass away.

27.verse: But You are the same, You will never change; Your years will never come to an end.

28.verse: The children of those who serve You will enjoy a good, long life; their offspring will stand strong before You.

1.verse: Psalm 103 - A song of David. O my soul, come, praise the Eternal with all that is in me—body, emotions, mind, and will—every part of who I am— praise His holy name.

2.verse: O my soul, come, praise the Eternal; sing a song from a grateful heart; sing and never forget all the good He has done.

3.verse: Despite all your many offenses, He forgives and releases you. More than any doctor, He heals your diseases.

4.verse: He reaches deep into the pit to deliver you from death. He crowns you with unfailing love and compassion like a king.

5.verse: When your soul is famished and withering, He fills you with good and beautiful things, satisfying you as long as you live. He makes you strong like an eagle, restoring your youth.

6.verse: When people are crushed, wronged, enslaved, raped, murdered, the Eternal is just; He makes the wrongs right.

7.verse: He showed Moses His ways; He allowed His people Israel to see His wonders and acts of power.

8.verse: The Eternal is compassionate and merciful. When we cross all the lines, He is patient with us. When we struggle against Him, He lovingly stays with us—changing, convicting, prodding;

9.verse: He will not constantly criticize, nor will He hold a grudge forever.

10.verse: Thankfully, God does not punish us for our sins and depravity as we deserve. In His mercy, He tempers justice with peace.

11.verse: Measure how high heaven is above the earth; God’s wide, loving, kind heart is greater for those who revere Him.

12.verse: You see, God takes all our crimes—our seemingly inexhaustible sins—and removes them. As far as east is from the west, He removes them from us.

13.verse: An earthly father expresses love for his children; it is no different with our heavenly Father; The Eternal shows His love for those who revere Him.

14.verse: For He knows what we are made of; He knows our frame is frail, and He remembers we came from dust.

15.verse: The children of Adam are like grass; their days are few; they flourish for a time like flowers in a meadow.

16.verse: As the wind blows over the field and the bloom is gone, it doesn’t take much to blow us out of the memory of that place.

17.verse: But the unfailing love of the Eternal is always and eternal for those who reverently run after Him. He extends His justice on and on to future generations,

18.verse: To those who will keep His bond of love and remember to walk in the guidance of His commands.

19.verse: The Eternal has established His throne up in the heavens. He rules over every seen and unseen realm and creature.

20.verse: Adore Him! Give Him praise, you heavenly messengers, you powerful creatures who listen to and act on His every word.

21.verse: Give praise to the Eternal, all armies of heaven— you servants who stand ready to do His will.

22.verse: Give praise to the Eternal, all that He has made in all corners of His creation. O my soul, come, praise the Eternal!

1.verse: Psalm 104 - Call Him good, my soul, and praise the Eternal. I am here to declare my affection for You, Eternal One, my God. You are indeed great— You who are wrapped in glory and dressed in greatness.

2.verse: For covering, You choose light—Your clothes, sunset and moonrise. For a tent, You stretch out the heavens; for Your roof, You pitch the sky.

3.verse: Your upper chamber is built on beams that lie in the waters overhead, and the clouds, Your chariot; You are held aloft by the wind.

4.verse: You make Your messengers like the winds; the breeze whispers Your words, Your servants are like the fire and flame.

5.verse: You made the earth, and You made its frame stable forever. Never will it be shaken.

6.verse: You wrapped it in a gown of waters— ancient mountains under layers of sky.

7.verse: But when You reprimanded those waters, they fled; the thunder of Your voice sent them running away.

8.verse: They hammered out new depths, heaved up new heights, and swallowed up whatever You commanded. At first, they covered the earth, but now You have bound them, and they know their appointed place.

9.verse: They hammered out new depths, heaved up new heights, and swallowed up whatever You commanded. At first, they covered the earth, but now You have bound them, and they know their appointed place.

10.verse: You send fresh streams that spring up in the valleys, in the cracks between hills.

11.verse: Every animal of the open field makes its journey there for drink: wild donkeys lap at the brooks’ edges.

12.verse: Birds build their nests by the streams, singing among the branches.

13.verse: And the clouds, too, drink up their share, raining it back down on the mountains from the upper reaches of Your home, Sustaining the whole earth with what comes from You. And the earth is satisfied.

14.verse: Thus You grow grain for bread, grapes for wine, grass for cattle— all of this for us. And so we have bread to make our bodies strong, wine to make our hearts happy, oil to make our faces shine. Every good thing we need, Your earth provides; our faces grow flush with Your life in them.

15.verse: Thus You grow grain for bread, grapes for wine, grass for cattle— all of this for us. And so we have bread to make our bodies strong, wine to make our hearts happy, oil to make our faces shine. Every good thing we need, Your earth provides; our faces grow flush with Your life in them.

16.verse: The forests are Yours, Eternal One—stout hardwoods watered deeply, swollen with sap— like the great cedars of Lebanon You planted,

17.verse: Where many birds nest. There are fir trees for storks,

18.verse: High hills for wild goats, stony cliffs for rock badgers. For each place, a resident, and for each resident, a home.

19.verse: The moon strides through her phases, marking seasons as she goes. The sun hides at his appointed time,

20.verse: And with the darkness You bring, so comes night— when the prowling animals of the forest move about.

21.verse: It is then that lions seek the food You, the True God, give them, roaring after their prey.

22.verse: At sunrise, they disappear and sleep away the day in their dens.

23.verse: Meanwhile, the people take to the fields and to the shops and to the roads, to all the places that people work, until evening when they rest.

24.verse: There is so much here, O Eternal One, so much You have made. By the wise way in which You create, riches and creatures fill the earth.

25.verse: Of course, the sea is vast and stretches like the heavens beyond view, and numberless creatures inhabit her. From the tiny to the great, they swarm beneath her waves.

26.verse: Our ships skim her surface while the monsters of the sea play beneath.

27.verse: And all of these look to You to give them food when the time is right.

28.verse: When You feed, they gather what You supply. When You open Your hand, they are filled with good food.

29.verse: When You withdraw Your presence, they are dismayed. When You revoke their breath, the life goes out of them, and they become, again, the dust of the earth from which You formed them at the start.

30.verse: When You send out Your breath, life is created, and the face of the earth is made beautiful and is renewed.

31.verse: May the glorious presence of the Eternal linger among us forever. And may He rejoice in the greatness of His own works—

32.verse: He, who rattles the earth with a glance; He, who sets mountains to smoking with a touch.

33.verse: I will sing to the Eternal all of my life; I will call my God good as long as I live.

34.verse: The last phrase of Psalm 104, “Praise the Eternal,” gives us a clear picture of the use of these songs in Israel. This phrase, which not only ends Psalm 104 but often opens and closes other psalms (for example, Psalms 146–150), is not part of the song itself. It is a direction for worship. The Bible indicates that praise is the natural response to God’s gifts to His people. When David brought the covenant chest to Jerusalem, he appointed Asaph and his relatives to lead in praise. After the Levites chanted a marvelous psalm, the people responded in praise to the Eternal (1 Chronicles 16:36). In John’s vision of the final destruction of Babylon—a symbol for God’s enemies throughout all the ages—a vast number of creatures in heaven, the 24 elders and the 4 living creatures offer praise and adoration to the Lord (Revelation 18 and 19). Praise is simply the inevitable response of God’s people to all He is and all He has done. May the thoughts of my mind be pleasing to Him, for the Eternal has become my happiness.

35.verse: But may those who hate Him, who act against Him, disappear from the face of this beautiful planet. As for the Eternal, call Him good, my soul. Praise the Eternal!

1.verse: Psalm 105 - Come, offer thanks to the Eternal; invoke His holy name. Tell other people about the things He has done.

2.verse: Sing songs of praise to Him; tell stories of all His miracles.

3.verse: Revel in His holy name. May the hearts of the people who seek the Eternal celebrate and experience great joy.

4.verse: Seek the Eternal and His power; look to His face constantly.

5.verse: Remember the wonderful things He has done, His miracles and the wise decisions He has made,

6.verse: O children of Abraham, His servant; O children of Jacob, His chosen people!

7.verse: He is the Eternal, our True God; His justice extends to every corner of the earth.

8.verse: He keeps His covenant promises forever and remembers the word He spoke to a thousand generations—

9.verse: The covenant He made with Abraham and His sworn oath to Isaac, his son.

10.verse: Then God confirmed it to Jacob—decreed it so— to Israel He promised a never-ending covenant,

11.verse: Saying, “I will give you the land of Canaan as your part; it will be your inheritance.”

12.verse: When God’s people were only a few in number— indeed, very few—they were strangers in a foreign land.

13.verse: They roamed from place to place, from one kingdom to another.

14.verse: God didn’t allow anyone to tyrannize them; He rebuked kings in order to protect His people:

15.verse: “Do not lay a hand on My anointed people; do not do any harm to My prophets.”

16.verse: He ordered famine to grip the land and cut them off from their supply of bread.

17.verse: But long before, He had sent a man ahead of them: Joseph, who had been sold into slavery.

18.verse: At first, his masters shackled his feet with chains, placed his neck into a collar of iron.

19.verse: That was until the Eternal’s promises came to pass; His word tested Joseph and proved him worthy.

20.verse: The king sent out the order to release him from prison; the ruler of Egypt liberated him from the chains.

21.verse: Then he put Joseph in charge of the royal household, made him ruler of all the royal possessions,

22.verse: Allowed him to imprison the royal officials whenever he saw fit and impart wisdom to the elders in the land.

23.verse: Then, when the time was right, Israel also went to Egypt; Jacob resided as an alien in the land of Ham.

24.verse: And while they were there, the Eternal made His people prosperous; He made them stronger than their enemies.

25.verse: He turned the Egyptians’ hearts against His people to cheat and scheme against His servants.

26.verse: Then, He sent His servant Moses and Aaron, the men He had chosen.

27.verse: They did all the signs He planned for them to do among the Egyptians, and they performed miracles in the land of Ham.

28.verse: He sent darkness to cover the land; they did not stray from His word.

29.verse: At His command, their waters turned to blood; their fish began to die.

30.verse: Throngs of frogs covered the land, invading even in the chambers of their kings.

31.verse: At His command, a swarm of flies arrived, and gnats came over all their land.

32.verse: He caused hail to fall instead of rain; lightning flashed over all their land.

33.verse: He struck their vines and their fig trees; He destroyed the trees over all their land.

34.verse: At His command, locusts came; young locusts marched beyond number,

35.verse: And they ate up all the plants that grew and all the fruits over their land.

36.verse: He also brought death to the firstborn in all their land, the first offspring of each man.

37.verse: Then He brought His people out of slavery, weighed down with silver and gold; and of all His tribes, not one of them stumbled, not one was left behind.

38.verse: Egypt was glad to see them go, for Pharaoh’s people had been overcome with fear of them.

39.verse: He spread out a cloud to cover His people and sent a fire to light their way at night.

40.verse: They asked, and He sent them coveys of quail, satisfying their hunger with the food of heaven.

41.verse: He split the rock and water poured out; it flowed like a river through the desert.

42.verse: For He remembered His holy covenant with Abraham, His servant.

43.verse: That’s why He rescued His people joyously and why His chosen ones celebrated with shouts and singing.

44.verse: When the time was right, He gave them land from other nations so that they might possess the works of their hands,

45.verse: So that they would be able to keep His commands and obey His laws. Praise the Eternal!

1.verse: Psalm 106 - Praise the Eternal! Thank Him because He is good and His loyal love will never end.

2.verse: Who could find words to tell of the Eternal’s mighty deeds or give Him all the praise He deserves?

3.verse: Blessed are those who work for justice, who always do what they know to be right!

4.verse: Remember me, O Eternal One, when You show kindness to Your people; don’t forget me when You are saving them.

5.verse: That way I can know how good it is to be Your chosen people; that way I can celebrate the joy of Your nation; that way I can join those who belong to You in unending praise.

6.verse: Psalm 106 was composed during the exile offering a historical review of the ways God’s people rebelled against Him. It is a fitting closure to Book Four of Psalms. After this liturgy of failure on the part of the people, the psalmist cries out in thanksgiving for God’s faithfulness and in the final verse proclaims praise “from everlasting to everlasting.” Like our ancestors, we have sinned; we have done wicked things.

7.verse: When our ancestors were leaving Egypt, they did not consider Your marvelous acts. They forgot Your overwhelming kindness to them and instead rebelled at the Red Sea.
